[[Foreign relations of Northern Cyprus|Recognised]] only by Turkey. | {{lang-tr|Kuzey Kıbrıs — Kuzey Kıbrıs Türk Cumhuriyeti}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cm.gov.nc.tr/|title=Kuzey Kıbrıs Türk Cumhuriyeti Cumhuriyet Meclisi |publisher=Kuzey Kıbrıs Türk Cumhuriyeti |accessdate=2018-03-15|language=Turkish}} | [[North Nicosia]]

{{lang-tr|Lefkoşa}}{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/country_profiles/1016541.stm |title=Cyprus country profile |publisher=BBC News |date=27 May 2011 |accessdate=3 August 2011}} | 285,356{{cite web|url=http://www.kibrispostasi.com/index.php/cat/35/news/40123/PageName/KIBRIS_HABERLERI |title=DPÖ: "2009 sonu itibarıyla nüfus 285 bin 356" |publisher=Kibris Postasi |date=8 October 2010 |accessdate=8 August 2011}} | {{convert|3355|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}} |- | [[File:Flag of South Ossetia.svg|centre|100px|border|link=Flag of South Ossetia|alt=Flag of South Ossetia]] | [[File:Location of South Ossetia in Europe2.png|150px]] | [[South Ossetia]]

Republic of South Ossetia | Claimed as [[Administrative divisions of Georgia (country)|part]] of [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/country_profiles/3797729.stm |title=Regions and territories: South Ossetia |publisher=BBC News |date=8 February 2011 |accessdate=8 August 2011}} Recognised by [[International recognition of Abkhazia and South Ossetia#UN member states|five UN states]]. | {{lang-os|Хуссар Ирыстон — Республикæ Хуссар Ирыстон}} (''{{Transl|os|Khussar Iryston — Respublikæ Khussar Iryston}}'')

{{lang-os|Цхинвал or Чъреба}} (''{{Transl|os|Chreba}}''){{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} | 70,000 | {{convert|3900|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hartford-hwp.com/archives/63/129.html |title=South Ossetia |author=Kafkas Vakfi |publisher=Hartford Web Publishing |accessdate=8 August 2011}} |} ==Dependent territories and other territories== {{further|Dependent territory}} The four entities in this list are controlled by a state of which they are not considered to be a part. {| class="wikitable sortable" ! class="unsortable" | Flag ! class="unsortable" | Map ! {{lang-en|Episkopi Cantonment}} | 15,700{{Cref2|e}} | {{convert|254|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}} |- | [[File:Flag of the British Indian Ocean Territory.svg|centre|100px|border|link=Union Flag|alt=Flag of the United Kingdom, as used in the British Indian Ocean Territory]] | [[File:British Indian Ocean Territory in United Kingdom.svg|150px]] | [[British Indian Ocean Territory]] | [[British Overseas Territories|British overseas territory]] | {{lang-en|British Indian Ocean Territory}} | — | 4,000{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/io.html |title=British Indian Ocean Territory |publisher=CIA |accessdate=14 August 2011}}{{Cref2|f}} | {{convert|54400|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}} |- | [[File:Flag of Christmas Island.svg|centre|100px|border|link=Flag of Christmas Island|alt=Flag of Christmas Island]] | [[File:Christmas_Island_on_the_globe_(Southeast_Asia_centered).svg|150px]] | [[Christmas Island]]

English short and formal names ! Status ! Domestic short and formal names ! Capital ! Population ! Area |- | [[File:Flag of Hong Kong.svg|centre|100px|border|link=Flag of Hong Kong|alt=Flag of Hong Kong]] | [[File:LocationHongKong.png|150px]] | [[Hong Kong]]

Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China | [[Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China]] | {{zh|香港 — 中華人民共和國香港特別行政區}}

{{lang-en|Hong Kong — Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China}} | [[Government Hill|Hong Kong]] | 7,122,508 | {{convert|1104|km2|sqmi|0|abbr=on}} |- | [[File:Flag of Macau.svg|centre|100px|border|link=Flag of Macau|alt=Flag of Macau]] | [[File:LocationMacau.png|150px]] | [[Macau]] / Macao

Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of ChinaAs reflected in the Chinese text of the Macau emblem, the text of the [http://bo.io.gov.mo/bo/i/1999/leibasica/index_uk.asp Macao Basic Law] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120205042947/http://bo.io.gov.mo/bo/i/1999/leibasica/index_uk.asp |date=5 February 2012 }}, and the [http://www.gov.mo/egi/Portal/index.htm Macao Government Website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120629213931/http://www.gov.mo/egi/Portal/index.htm |date=29 June 2012 }}, the full name of the territory is the Macao Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China. Although the conventions of "Macao Special Administrative Region", "Macao" and "Macau" can also be used. | [[Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China]] | {{zh|澳門 — 中華人民共和國澳門特別行政區}}

{{lang-pt|Macau — Região Administrativa Especial de Macau da República Popular da China}} | [[Macau]] / Macao | 573,003 | {{convert|28.2|km2|sqmi|1|abbr=on}} |} ==See also== * [[List of Asian countries by GDP]] * [[List of predecessors of sovereign states in Asia]] ==Notes== {{Cnote2 Begin}} {{Cnote2|a|n=1|Area and population figures given are for the whole state, including areas located outside of Asia. Azerbaijan, Georgia, Kazakhstan, Russia, and Turkey all contain territory in Europe. The border between Asia and Oceania is not clearly defined, and Indonesia and East Timor are sometimes placed in Oceania.}} {{Cnote2|b|n=4|The area and population of states with separatist regions includes that of the separatist regions.}} {{Cnote2|c|Jerusalem was declared the capital of Israel in 1950.{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/is.html |title=Middle East :: Israel |publisher=CIA |accessdate=10 August 2011}} The 1980 [[Jerusalem Law]] states that "Jerusalem, complete and united, is the capital of Israel", and the city serves as the seat of the government, home to the President's residence, government offices, supreme court, and [[Knesset|parliament]].{{cite web|url=https://www.knesset.gov.il/laws/special/eng/basic10_eng.htm |title=Basic Law: Jerusalem, Capital of Israel |publisher=The Knesset |accessdate=10 August 2011}} [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 478]] declared the Jerusalem Law "null and void" and called on member states to withdraw their diplomatic missions from Jerusalem.{{Cite press release|title=Resolution 478 |publisher=United Nations Security Council |year=1980 |url=http://daccess-dds-ny.un.org/doc/RESOLUTION/GEN/NR0/399/71/IMG/NR039971.pdf?OpenElement |accessdate=10 August 2011}} Foreign countries maintain their embassies in Tel Aviv and other Israeli cities.[https://www.science.co.il/Embassies.php Embassies and Consulates in Israel], Israel Science and Technology Directory}} {{Cnote2|d|Although Kuala Lumpur is the official capital of Malaysia, [[Putrajaya]] is the seat of government.{{cite web |url=http://www.malaysia.gov.my/EN/Main/MsianGov/PutrajayaFederalAdminCapital/Pages/PutrajayaFederalAdminCapital.aspx |title=Putrajaya - Federal Administrative Capital |publisher=Malaysian Government |accessdate=15 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110829013340/http://www.malaysia.gov.my/EN/Main/MsianGov/PutrajayaFederalAdminCapital/Pages/PutrajayaFederalAdminCapital.aspx |archivedate=29 August 2011 |df=dmy-all }}}} {{Cnote2|e|Akrotiri and Dhekelia are British military bases, with the population including 8,000 United Kingdom personnel and dependents.{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ax.html |title=Akrotiri |publisher=CIA |accessdate=14 August 2011}}}} {{Cnote2|f|Although the islands have no remaining indigenous inhabitants, a military base shared between the [[United Kingdom]] and the [[United States]] is located on the island of [[Diego Garcia]], with a staff of 4,000 people.}} {{Cnote2|g|Represents total land area. Including claimed ocean area, total area 54,400 km2 (21,004 sq mi).}} {{Cnote2 End}} {{reflist|group=n}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}} {{Countries of Asia}} {{Lists of countries by continent}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sovereign States And Dependent Territories In Asia, List Of}} [[Category:Lists of countries in Asia| ]] [[Category:Countries in Asia|*]] [[Category:Asia-related lists]] [[fr:Asie#Géographie politique]]

page.title: List of typefaces included with Microsoft Windows

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2017}} __NOTOC__ This is a list of typefaces shipped with [[Windows 3.1x]] through [[Windows 10]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.siao2.com/2007/02/06/1607855.aspx |title=What are the fonts in Vista? |last=Kaplan |first=Michael S. |date=6 February 2007 |website=Sorting it all Out V.. 2! |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140625120101/http://www.siao2.com/2007/02/06/1607855.aspx |archive-date=25 June 2014 |dead-url=yes}}{{Cite web |url=http://www.ampsoft.net/webdesign-l/windows-fonts-by-version.html |title=Fonts included with each version of Windows |last=Martinez Perez |first=Alberto |date=18 May 2008 |website=ampsoft.net}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.microsoft.com/typography/fonts/product.aspx?PID=149 |title=Fonts supplied with Windows Vista |website=Typography |publisher=Microsoft |access-date=21 October 2013}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.microsoft.com/typography/fonts/product.aspx?PID=161 |title=Fonts supplied with Windows 7 |website=Typography |publisher=Microsoft |access-date=21 October 2013}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.microsoft.com/typography/fonts/product.aspx?PID=164 |title=Fonts supplied with Windows 8 |website=Typography |publisher=Microsoft |access-date=21 October 2013}}{{Cite web |url=https://msdn.microsoft.com/globalization/mt791278 |title=Script and Font Support in Windows |publisher=Microsoft |access-date=8 May 2015}} Typefaces only shipped with [[Microsoft Office]] or other Microsoft applications are not included. The "First Windows version" column indicates the [[List of Microsoft Windows versions|first edition of Windows]] in which the font was included. This list may be incomplete. revision.comment: Frisia has a population over 2.65m and is thus very clearly not an uninhabited region
revision.text:
{{redirect|Uninhabited|the 2010 Australian horror film|Uninhabited (film)}} [[File:World_population_density_1994 - with equator.png|thumb|350px|Map of world population, showing uninhabited or nearly uninhabited areas in grey.]] The '''list of uninhabited regions''' includes a number of places around the globe. The list changes year over year as human beings migrate into formerly uninhabited regions, or migrate out of formerly inhabited regions.
==List== As a group, the list of uninhabited places are called the "nonecumene". This is a special geography term which means the uninhabited area of the world.<ref>Gosh, Ajay Kumar. (2005). [https://books.google.com/books?id=ua5hMZ-Ie3UC&pg=PA84&dq= ''Academic Dictionary Of Geology,'' p. 84].</ref> {{dynamic list}} *Sviten * Virtually all of [[Antarctica]]<ref>[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ay.html "Antarctica" at ''CIA World Factbook'' (CIA)]; excerpt, "no indigenous inhabitants, but there are both permanent and summer-only staffed research stations"; retrieved 2013-4-19.</ref> * [[Antipodes Islands]] * [[Ashmore and Cartier Islands]]<ref>[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/at.html "Ashmore and Cartier Islands" at CIA]; excerpt, "no indigenous inhabitants"; retrieved 2013-4-19.</ref> * Much of [[Australia]] * [[Bajo Nuevo Bank]] * [[Baker Island]]<ref>[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/um.html "Baker Island" at CIA]; excerpt, "no indigenous inhabitants"; retrieved 2013-4-19.</ref> * [[Ball's Pyramid]] * [[Balleny Islands]] * [[Barren Grounds|Much of interior Nunavut]] * [[Big Major Cay]] * [[Bouvet Island]]<ref>[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/bv.html "Bouvet Island" at CIA]; retrieved 2013-4-19.</ref> * [[Caroline Island]] * [[Clipperton Island]] * [[Devon Island]] * Much of [[Eastern Oregon]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Southeast Oregon|url=http://www.americansouthwest.net/oregon/southeast/index.html|website=americansouthwest|publisher=The American Southwest|accessdate=27 July 2017}}</ref> * [[Elephant Island]] * [[Elobey Chico]] * [[Ernst Thälmann Island]] * Much of inland [[Greenland]] * [[Gough Island]] * [[Hans Island]] * [[Harmil]] * [[Hashima Island]]<ref>Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). [https://books.google.com/books?id=p2QnPijAEmEC&pg=PA294&dq= "Hashima"] in ''Japan Encyclopedia'', p. 294.</ref> * [[Hatutu]] * [[Heard Island and McDonald Islands]]<ref>[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/hm.html "Heard and McDonald Islands" at CIA]; retrieved 2013-4-19.</ref> * Much of Iceland, especially [[Highlands of Iceland|its highlands]] * The upper [[Alpine climate|alpine zone]] and [[Snow line|nival zone]] of the [[Himalaya]] (and most other high mountains). * [[Howland Island]]<ref>[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/um.html "Howland Island" at CIA]; excerpt, "no indigenous inhabitants"; retrieved 2013-4-19.</ref> * [[Ilha da Queimada Grande]] *[[Inisshark]] * [[Jaco Island]] * [[Jarvis Island]]<ref>[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/um.html "Jarvis Island" at CIA]; excerpt, "no indigenous inhabitants"; retrieved 2013-4-19.</ref> * [[Jong Batu]] * [[Kahoolawe Island]] * [[Kerguelen Islands]] * [[Kingman Reef]]<ref>[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/um.html "Kingman Reef" at CIA]; excerpt, "no indigenous inhabitants"; retrieved 2013-4-19.</ref> * [[Mborokua]] * [[Minquiers and Ecréhous]] * [[Melville Island (Northwest Territories and Nunavut)|Melville Island]] * [[Monomoy Island]] * [[Prince Edward Islands]] * [[Navassa Island]]<ref>[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/bq.html "Navassa Island" at CIA]; retrieved 2013-4-19.</ref> * [[Nomans Land]] * Much of Northern [[British Columbia]] * Much of [[Northern Ontario]] * [[Paracel Islands]]<ref>[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/pf.html "Paracel Islands" at CIA]; excerpt, "no indigenous inhabitants"; retrieved 2013-4-19.</ref> * [[Palmyra Atoll]]<ref>[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/um.html "Palmyra Atoll" at CIA]; excerpt, "no indigenous inhabitants"; retrieved 2013-4-19.</ref> * [[Redonda]] * [[Île Ronde, Mauritius|Round Island]] * [[South Orkney Islands]] * [[Spratly Islands]]<ref>[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/pg.html "Spratly Islands" at CIA]; excerpt, "no indigenous inhabitants"; retrieved 2013-4-19.</ref> * [[Stirling Island]] * Much of Northern [[Siberia]] * [[Siwalik]] (outermost Himalayan foothills) and surrounding [[alluvial fan|alluvial skirt]] [[Bhabar]] in [[Geography of India|India]], [[Geography of Pakistan|Pakistan]], [[Geography of Nepal|Nepal]] and [[Geography of Bhutan|Bhutan]], apparently due to endemic [[malaria]] and droughty soils. * [[St Kilda, Scotland|St Kilda]] * [[Tetepare Island]] * [[Geography of Tibet|Tibet's]] upper [[Alpine climate|alpine zone]] and [[Snow line|nival zone]]. * [[Tinakula]] * [[Tumucumaque National Park]] in northwest Brazil<ref>[http://news.mongabay.com/2006/1114-google_earth-act.html Tumucumaque National Park] {{webarchive|url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20071007195006/http://news.mongabay.com/2006/1114-google_earth-act.html |date=2007-10-07 }} A 14Nov2006 Mongabay.com article primarily about a different inhabited area, which however does reliably document ''this large uninhabited area''.</ref>
==See also== *[[Desert island]] *[[List of ghost towns]] *[[Private island]] *[[Terra Nullius]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Uninhabited Regions}} [[Category:Lists by region]] [[Category:Human geography]] [[Category:Uninhabited islands]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{distinguish|text=the [[Nazi]] purge known as the [[Night of the Long Knives (1934)]]}} '''Long knives''' or '''big knives''' was a term used by the [[Iroquois]], and later by the [[Mingo]] and other [[North American Indians|Natives]] of the [[Ohio Country]] to designate British colonists of [[Virginia]], in contradistinction to those of [[New York State|New York]] and [[Pennsylvania]].
It is a literal translation of the treaty name that the Iroquois first bestowed on Virginia Governor [[Francis Howard, 5th Baron Howard of Effingham|Lord Howard]] in 1684, ''Assarigoe'' (variously spelled ''Assaregoa, Assaragoa, Asharigoua''), meaning "[[cutlass]]" in Onondaga. This word was chosen as a pun on Howard's name, which sounds like Dutch ''hower'' meaning "cutlass"<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=MZurlZfg1fAC&pg=PA141&dq=hower+cutlass&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiI8IuV5O3NAhUERiYKHR2OAp44FBDoAQhLMAk#v=onepage&q=hower%20cutlass contemporary 17th c. source affirming Dutch ''hower'' = "cutlass"]</ref> (similar to the Iroquois' choice of the name ''Onas'', or "quill pen", for the Pennsylvania Governors, beginning with William Penn.) This is the very explanation included within official diplomatic correspondence addressed by the Iroquois sachems themselves to then-governor Spotswood in 1722. <ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=8DJEAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA251&dq=hower+cutlass&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiI8IuV5O3NAhUERiYKHR2OAp44FBDoAQg2MAU#v=onepage&q=hower%20cutlass Iroquois-Virginia negotiations of 1722] - (note the date 1784 is incorrectly printed here for 1684).</ref>
[[George Rogers Clark]] spoke of himself and men as "Big Knives" or Virginians, in his speeches to the Indians in 1778 after the [[Battle of Vincennes|capture of Illinois]]. In the latter part of the [[American Revolutionary War]], down to and during the [[War of 1812]], the term was used to designate "Americans".
==References== <references /> * ''Dictionary of American History'' by [[James Truslow Adams]], New York: Charles Scribner's Sons, 1940. *[https://books.google.com/books?id=vGn7e2hidwgC&pg=PA78&lpg=PA78&dq=mingo+junction+long+knives&source=bl&ots=JhwmEONk4O&sig=l0Nw2BoRSzmgCc1zSD93dhW7CKk&hl=en&sa=X&ei=SvEsUcP1Fczv0QHPuoCoAQ&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=mingo%20junction%20long%20knives&f=false Chronicles of Border Warfare: "A history of whites and of the Indian Wars and Massacres", Alexander Scott Withers, 1831 p78-79.]
[[Category:Colonial Virginia]] [[Category:Native American history of Virginia]] [[Category:Exonyms]] [[Category:American Revolutionary War]] [[Category:War of 1812]] [[Category:Iroquois]]

{{refimprove|date=November 2013}} {{original research|date=November 2013}} '''Lower Kolašin''' ([[Montenegrin language|Montenegrin]] and {{lang-sr-cyr|Доњи Колашин/Donji Kolašin}}) is a historical region<ref>{{cite book|title=Гласник Етнографског института|volume=22-24|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4oQjAQAAIAAJ|year=1973|publisher=Научно дело|page=51}}</ref> in the present-day municipality of [[Bijelo Polje]] in northern [[Montenegro]], towards [[Serbia]]. It is situated in the picturesque Vraneš valley formed around the river [[Ljuboviđa]]. The most important local populated centers are [[Tomaševo]] and [[Pavino Polje]].
==Geography== Lower Kolašin is a region situated in the northern part of Montenegro, at the border with Serbia. It is located between the rivers of [[Tara (river)|Tara]], [[Ljuboviđa]], left tributary of [[Lim (river)|Lim river]] and source of the Ćeotina.<ref name="Marković1967">{{cite book|author=Jovan Đ Marković|title=Geografske oblasti Socijalističke Federativne Republike Jugoslavije|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QlwMAQAAIAAJ|year=1967|publisher=Zavod za izdavanje udžbenika Socijalističke Republike Srbije|quote=Крај око Мојковца познат је као Горњи Колашин. Северно од њега (између Таре, Љубовиђе, леве притоке Лима и изворишта Ћеотине) налази се Доњи Колашин.}}</ref> It is located at the left side of the [[Lim (river)|Lim river]], and its central part is made up of the valley of the [[Vraneš (river)|Vraneš river]].<ref name="zadruga1913">{{cite book|author=Srpska književna zadruga|title=Izdanja|issue=154|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vyVaAAAAYAAJ|year=1913|page=286|quote=У средњем веку у овом крају била је Бихорска Жупа. На супротној страни од Бихора, на левој страни Лима, настаје област Доњи Колашин, чији централни део чини долина реке Вранеша. Област шумовита, богата пашама, ...}}</ref> To the south lies the region of Upper Kolašin, around [[Mojkovac]].<ref name="Marković1967"/> On the other side of the Lim is the region of [[Bihor (region)|Bihor]].<ref name="zadruga1913"/>
==History== ===Middle Ages=== The Ljuboviđa ''[[župa]]'' (county) was mentioned in medieval documents beginning in 1281. It was named after a river that passed through the Vraneš valley. The county included an area from the [[Tara (river)|Tara]] in the west, beyond the Lim to the east, from [[Brodarevo]] in the north to south of [[Mojkovac]].{{cn|date=January 2016}}
The [[Ottoman Empire]] first established its rule in the region in 1396, and managed to occupy the entire area by 1463–65, making it part of the [[Sanjak of Herzegovina]].{{cn|date=January 2016}} The first Ottoman censuses from 1468 and 1477 reveal that the local administrator at that time was one Herak Vraneš, a native.{{cn|date=January 2016}}
===19th century=== According to the [[Treaty of San Stefano]] (3 March 1878), the region was to be ceded to the [[Principality of Montenegro]], however, it was never implemented. With the [[Congress of Berlin]] (13 July 1878), the Austro-Hungarians obtained the right to station garrisons in the [[Sanjak of Novi Pazar]]. In 1880, the [[Sanjak of Sjenica]] (the new Sanjak of Novi Pazar) was established, which included the ''[[kaza]]'' (districts) of [[Sjenica]] (its seat), [[Nova Varoš]], [[Bijelo Polje]] and Lower Kolašin (part of modern [[Bijelo Polje]] and [[Mojkovac]] municipalities).<ref name="Petrović1995-8">{{cite book|author=Milić F. Petrović|title=Dokumenti o Raškoj oblasti: 1900-1912|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L1K5AAAAIAAJ|year=1995|publisher=Arhiv Srbije|page=8|quote=Да би сузбила аустроугарски утицај у западним крајевима Рашке области, Турска је извршила нову управну поделу. Новопазарски санџак је 1879. год. издвојен из Босанског вилајста и прикључен Косовеком вилајету, који је основан још 1877. год. са седиштем у Приштини а касније у Скопљу. Потом је 1880. године основан пљеваљ- ски санџак — мутесарифлук тј. округ саседиштем у Пљевљима, који је обухватио казе Пљевља, Пријеноље и мундирлук - испоставу у Прибоју. Тосу места у којимасу се налазили аустро-угарски гарнизони. Исте године формиран је Новопазарски, одно- сно Сјенички санџак са седиштем у Сјеници, а који је обухватио казе: сјеничку, нововарошку, бјелопољску и доњоколашинску (територија данашњих општина Би- јело Поље и ...}}</ref>
In 1886, Lower Kolašin was ceded to Montenegro. That same year, all Muslim families emigrated to Turkey. The abandoned land was settled by rebels from this area and neighbouring ones, by Prince [[Nikola I Petrović-Njegoš]].<ref name="Bulajić1959">{{cite book|author=Žarko Bulajić|title=Agrarni odnosi u Crnoj Gori, 1878-1912|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MWjJAAAAMAAJ|year=1959|publisher=Grafički Zavod|quote=Поља Колашинска, или Доњи Колашин, ослобођена су тек 1886 године.19): Исте године су и све муслиманске породице еми- грирале у Турску. Њихову напуштену земљу је књаз даровао устаницима из ових и других сусједних крајева, који су све до ове године били склоњени заједно са стоком у планину Сиња- јевину.20) Међу овим устаницима био јје и велики број становника Колашинских Поља, ...}}</ref>
===20th century=== In 1912, during the [[First Balkan War]], [[Montenegro]] occupied Lower Kolašin on 12 October 1912, imposing a rule of terror and fear over the local Muslim population.{{cn|date=January 2016}} Shortly thereafter, the three local municipalities were formed in Lower Kolašin with centers in [[Tomaševo]], [[Pavino Polje]], and [[Stozer]]. Mass killings of local Muslim population led to their widespread migration to [[Turkey]].
After the local Montenegrin administrator, [[Boško Bošković]] was murdered near [[Obod]] by his countrymen, the Montenegrin nationalists used that as an excuse to blame a local Muslim, [[Jusuf Mehonić]], for the murder, which would open a way for the complete expulsion of Muslims from Lower Kolašin. On 9–10 November 1924, armed hordes of Montenegrin peasants massacred up to 600–700 Muslims in Lower Kolašin, committing the most atrocious crimes. Following this event, all surviving Muslims left Lower Kolašin, relocating to other parts of [[Sandžak]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] or [[Turkey]]. One family converted to Orthodox Christianity, saving itself from physical extermination.{{cn|date=January 2016}}
==Demographics== The present-day population of Lower Kolašin is 4,300, all [[Serbs]] and [[Montenegrins (ethnic group)|Montenegrins]].
Prior to the massacre in 1924, according to the census in 1912, Lower Kolašin had 14,838 inhabitants, with the following ethnic distribution:
* Mojkovac municipality: Muslims 1,581, Serbs 1,293 * Ravna Rijeka municipality: Muslims 2,003, Serbs 679 * Stozer municipality: Muslims 1,160, Serbs 1,971 * Pavino Polje municipality: Muslims 3,230, Serbs 641; * Tomaševo municipality: Muslims 2,132, Serbs 119
In percentages, the overall breakdown is: * Muslims: 10,106 or 68.1% * [[Serbs]]: 4,703 or 31.7% * Others: 29 or 0.2%
==Anthropology== Muslim families that left after the 1924 massacre were the Hadžović, Kaljić and Kolić, among others.
==See also== *[[Upper Kolašin]] *[[Ibarski Kolašin]] (North Kosovo)
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Geographical regions of Montenegro}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Lower Kolasin}} [[Category:Sandžak|*]] [[Category:Geography of Montenegro]]

{{Infobox Political post |post = Minister-President |body =
the Brussels-Capital Region |insignia = Flag of the Brussels-Capital Region.svg |insigniasize = 100px |insigniacaption = [[Flag of the Brussels-Capital Region|Regional flag]] |termlength = Five years |residence = |image = |incumbent = [[Rudi Vervoort]] |incumbentsince = |formation = 12 June 1989 |inaugural = Charles Picqué }} {{Politics of Brussels}} The '''Minister-President of the Brussels Capital-Region''' ({{lang-fr|Région de Bruxelles-Capitale}}, {{lang-nl|Brussels Hoofdstedelijk Gewest}}) is the person leading the [[Government of the Brussels-Capital Region]].{{cite web|title=The Belgian Constitution (English version) |url=http://www.dekamer.be/kvvcr/pdf_sections/publications/constitution/grondwetEN.pdf |format=[[PDF]] |publisher=Belgian House of Representatives |date=January 2009 |accessdate=2009-06-05 |quote=Article 3: Belgium comprises three Regions: the Flemish Region, the Walloon Region and the Brussels region. Article 4: Belgium comprises four linguistic regions: the Dutch-speaking region, the French speaking region, the bilingual region of '''Brussels-Capital''' and the German-speaking region. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706134014/http://www.dekamer.be/kvvcr/pdf_sections/publications/constitution/grondwetEN.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-06 |df= }}{{cite web|title=Brussels-Capital Region: Creation |url=http://www.bruxelles.irisnet.be/en/region/region_de_bruxelles-capitale/creation.shtml |publisher=''Centre d'Informatique pour la Région Bruxelloise'' (Brussels Regional Informatics Center) |year=2009 |accessdate=2009-06-05 |quote=Since 18 June 1989, the date of the first regional elections, the '''Brussels-Capital Region''' has been an autonomous region comparable to the Flemish and Walloon Regions. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090429213057/http://www.bruxelles.irisnet.be/en/region/region_de_bruxelles-capitale/creation.shtml |archivedate=29 April 2009 |df= }} (All text and all but one graphic show the English name as '''Brussels-Capital Region'''.) The post is appointed for 5 years along with 4 [[Political minister|minister]]s and 3 [[Secretary of State|"state" secretaries]]. While being the leader of the Government, the Minister-President also is the president of the College of the [[Common Community Commission]] of Brussels. The Minister-President of the Brussels-Capital Region should neither be confused with the [[Governor of Brussels-Capital]] nor with the [[mayor]] of the [[City of Brussels]], which is one of the [[Municipalities of the Brussels-Capital Region|19 municipalities of Brussels]]. The Minister-President is not counted in the ratio of French-speaking to Dutch-speaking ministers. In practice every Minister-President has been a francophone, though bilingual. ==List== {| width=75% class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" ! № ! Name

(1954–2010) | 6 June 2003 | 18 February 2004 | bgcolor=#90C2FB | MR |- ! style="background:{{BE party c|MR}}; color:white"| (2) | '''[[Jacques Simonet]]''' (''2nd term'')
(1963–2007) | 18 February 2004 | 19 July 2004 | bgcolor=#90C2FB | MR |- ! style="background:{{BE party c|PS}}; color:white"| (1) | '''[[Charles Picqué]]''' (''2nd term'')

page.title: Minister of Mines and Technical Surveys

revision.text:
The '''Minister of Mines and Technical Surveys''' was a position in the [[Canadian Cabinet]] from 1950 to 1966.
The former offices of [[Minister of Mines and Resources]] and [[Minister of Reconstruction and Supply]] were abolished by Statute 13 Geo. VI, c. 18, and the offices of the [[Minister of Citizenship and Immigration]], Minister of Mines and Technical Surveys and [[Minister of Resources and Development]] created by Statutes 13 Geo. VI, c. 16, 17 and 18 respectively, each assented to on 10 Dec. 1949 and proclaimed in force on 18 Jan. 1950.
==Ministers 1950-1966== {| class="wikitable" |- |1. |[[James Joseph McCann]] | Cabinet of [[Louis St. Laurent|St. Laurent]] | January 18, 1950 – December 12, 1950 |- | 2. |[[George Prudham]] | Cabinet of [[Louis St. Laurent|St. Laurent]] | December 13, 1950 – June 21, 1957 |- | 3. | [[Léon Balcer]] ''acting'' | Cabinet of [[John George Diefenbaker|Diefenbaker]] | June 21, 1957 – August 6, 1957 |- | 4. | [[Paul Comtois]] | Cabinet of [[John George Diefenbaker|Diefenbaker]] | August 7, 1957 – October 6, 1961 |- | 5. | [[Walter Gilbert Dinsdale]] ''acting'' |Cabinet of [[John George Diefenbaker|Diefenbaker]] | October 10, 1961 – December 27, 1961 |- | 6. | [[Jacques Flynn]] | Cabinet of [[John George Diefenbaker|Diefenbaker]] | December 28, 1961 – July 12, 1962 |- | 7. | [[Hugh John Flemming]] ''acting'' | Cabinet of [[John George Diefenbaker|Diefenbaker]] | July 18, 1962 – August 8, 1962 |- | 8. | [[Paul Martineau]] | Cabinet of [[John George Diefenbaker|Diefenbaker]] | August 9, 1962 – April 22, 1963 |- | 9. | [[William Moore Benidickson]] | Cabinet of [[Lester Pearson|Pearson]] | April 22, 1963 – July 6, 1965 |- | 10. | [[John Watson MacNaught]] | Cabinet of [[Lester Pearson|Pearson]] | July 7, 1965 – December 17, 1965 |- | 11. | [[Jean-Luc Pepin]] | Cabinet of [[Lester Pearson|Pearson]] | December 18, 1965 – September 30, 1966 |}
The new position of [[Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources (Canada)|Minister of Energy, Mines and Resources]] was created on October 1, 1966.
==External links== *[https://www.buck-vermessung.de/karriere/ Buck Surveying]
[[Category:Canadian ministers|Mines and Technical Surveys]] [[Category:Mining ministers|Canada]] [[Category:Surveying organizations]]
{{Canada-gov-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=January 2011}} '''Planet Lofoten''' is a [[Land Art]] Installation of the [[solar system]] positioned in the open nature of West [[Lofoten]] in Northern [[Norway]].
The [[Planets]] are made from [[stone]] and range in size from Jupiter at several hundred kilograms to [[Pluto]] at only a few grams, and ranges within an area of 30 km from [[Reine]] at [[Moskenes]] Island to Nordland at [[Værøy]] Island. The [[Sun]] is still in the construction process<ref>[http://www.nfi.no/english/norwegianfilms/show.html?id=752 ''The Norwegian filminstitute''] Quote to Jan Wangaard in the documentary film "Alt Flyter (Panta Rei)."</ref> and will be a 7-meter diameter [[sphere]] made from [[steel]] circles, and will be placed at Reine in Lofoten.
The scale of Planet Lofoten is 1: 200 million.
The artist [[Jan Wanggaard]] says about the project that he intend nothing with the installation other than letting it stay there and maybe inspire people who bump into it in one or the other way ‒ as an artistic expression or a nice tool to help understand the size and proportions of the Solar System that we all live in.
The [[documentary film]] ''[[Alt Flyter]]'' (Panta Rei) by [[Lars Nilssen]] follows Wanggaard during the realization process of Planet Lofoten over a period of three years.
The documentary won [[Award for Creativity]] at FIFA, the worlds biggest [[Art Film Festival]] In [[Montreal]], [[Canada]] in 2007 and has since then been shown at several [[Art museum|galleries]] around the world including [[The Louvre]].
==See also== * [[Solar system model]] - A list of similar solar system models.
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.wanggaard.com/concept/projects/planet-lofoten/ Jan Wanggaard's page about the installation.]
[[Category:Lofoten]] [[Category:Land art]] [[Category:Solar System models]]

revision.text:
[[Image:Rahotep statue.jpg|thumb|180px|right|[[Rahotep]], a superintendent of the military, and military supplies, including archers–(Note Archer hieroglyph, and quiver hieroglyph).
(Superintendent-(overseer): is ''‘[[Emir]]’'', represented by the ''[[owl (hieroglyph)|Owl]]'' above ''[[mouth (hieroglyph)|mouth]]'' hieroglyphs, for ''"m-r"'', 'emeer'.) ]] The '''''Pítati''''' ('''''pí-ta-ti''''') were a contingent of [[archery|archers]] of [[ancient Egypt]] that were often requested and dispatched to support Egyptian [[vassal]]s in [[Canaan]]. They are recorded in the [[text corpus|correspondence]] of the [[1350 BC]] [[Amarna letters]], and were often requested to defend against the [[Habiru]], also rogue vassal-kings and foreign troops of neighboring kingdoms (for example, [[Hittites#History|Hatti]]), who were on the attack. The vassal cities and "[[city-state]]s" were constantly requesting the services-(protection) of the Pharaoh's armies, by means of this "archer-army" force, basically [[garrison]] forces. A request for lodging, and preparations of [[food]], [[drink]], [[straw]], and other supplies required,Moran, William L., 1992. ''The Amarna Letters,'' p. 352-353. ''EA 325'': Title: (from, Man of the City: [[Yidya]]): ''Preparations completed, (2)'',
"...indeed prepared absolutely everything—food, strong drink, oxen, 'sheep and goats', grain, straw, absolutely everything that the king, my lord, commanded." is often demanded by the pharaoh, for a small, or a large contingent. The pítati archer force were [[Mercenary|mercenaries]] from the southern Egyptian "land of [[Kingdom of Kush|Kush]]"-(named ''Kaša'', or ''Kaši'' in the letters). The first use of [[Nubians|Nubian]] [[mercenary|mercenaries]] was by [[Autobiography of Weni|Weni]] of the [[Sixth Dynasty of Egypt]] during the [[Old Kingdom of Egypt]], about [[2300 BC]]. ==A letter example--no. 337== A vassal–state letter example from Hiziru, a "mayor", often referred to as the "Man ([[Lugal]]) of the City", in ancient Palestine is [[Amarna letters|EA]] 337, entitled "Abundant supplies ready". The letter is short and undamaged: {{quote| Say to the king, my lord, my Sun, my god: Message of Hiziru, your servant. I [[prostration formula|fall at the feet]] of the king, my lord, 7 times and 7 times. The king, my lord, wrote to me, "Prepare the supplies before the arrival of a large army of''' '''''pí-ta-ti''''' '''of the king, [m]y l[ord]." May the god of the king, my lord, grant that the king, my lord, come forth along with his large army and learn about his lands. I have indeed prepared accordingly abundant supplies before the arrival of a large army of the king, my lord. The king, my lord, wrote to me, "Guard Maya," the [[commissioner]] of the king, my lord. Truly. I guard Maya very carefully. -EA 337, lines 1-30 (complete) }} =="Archers and myrrh"== Letter no. 3 of 5 by [[Milkilu]] of Gazru (modern [[Gezer]]): {{quote|Say to the god, my king, my lord, my Sun: Message of [[Milkilu]], your servant, the dirt at your feet. I [[prostration formula|fall at the feet]] of the god, my king, my lord, my Sun, 7 times and 7 times. I have heard what the king, my lord, wrote to me, and so may the king, my lord, send the ''[[Archery|archers]]'' to his servants, and may the king, my lord send [[myrrh]] for [[Pharmaceutical drug|medication]]. -EA 269, lines 1-17 (complete)}} ==Analysis== Part of the debate in analyzing the army-archer-force is whether the army just annually accompanied the pharaoh's commissioner or [[envoy (title)|envoy]] and were then extracting [[tribute]], or whether the archer-force duty was strictly military, and in support of the Egyptian borderlands control and influence. The short time period of the [[Amarna letters]], 15–20 years, (17?), may give an answer to the influence of the archer-forces. ==See also== *Letters from [[Yidya]], (EA 325) ==References== {{Commons category|Archer (hieroglyph)}} {{reflist}} *[[William L. Moran|Moran, William L.]], 1992. ''The Amarna Letters.'' Johns Hopkins University Press, 1987, 1992. (softcover, {{ISBN|0-8018-6715-0}}) {{DEFAULTSORT:Archers (Egyptian Pitati)}} [[Category:Canaan]] [[Category:Amarna Period]] [[Category:Amarna letters]] [[Category:History of archery]] [[Category:Egyptian archers]]

{{Infobox observatory}}
'''Ridge A''' is a site in [[Antarctica]] that was identified in 2009 as the best suited location on the surface of Earth for astronomical research.<ref name="Saunders et al. 2009">{{Citation |last=Saunders |first=Will |last2=Lawrence |first2=Jon S. |last3=Storey |first3=John W. V. |last4=Ashley |first4=Michael C. B. |last5=Kato |first5=Seiji |last6=Minnis |first6=Patrick |last7=Winker |first7=David M. |last8=Liu |first8=Guiping |last9=Kulesa |first9=Craig |lastauthoramp=yes |year=2009 |title=Where Is the Best Site on Earth? Domes A, B, C, and F, and Ridges A and B |journal=Publications of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific |volume=121 |issue=883 |pages=976–992 |doi=10.1086/605780 |issn= |bibcode=2009PASP..121..976S|arxiv = 0905.4156 }}</ref> The site, approximately {{convert|1000|km|mi}} from the [[South Pole]] and {{convert|144|km|mi}} southeast of [[Dome A]], is situated in a portion of Antarctica claimed by Australia in the [[Australian Antarctic Territory]].
The site is on the [[Antarctic Plateau]] at an altitude of {{convert|4053|m|ft}}, and has an average winter temperature of {{convert|-70|°C|°F|0}}. It is possible that this site may have even lower temperatures than Dome A.<ref name="Saunders et al. 2009"/><ref name="wond">{{citation |title = Ridge A - best place for astronomy research on Earth |publisher = Wondermondo |date = 27 September 2010 |url = http://www.wondermondo.com/Countries/An/Antarctica/Antarctica/RidgeA.htm}}</ref> Ridge A was identified by a team of Australian and American scientists searching for the best [[observatory]] spot in the world.<ref name="Saunders et al. 2009"/> The team leader described the site as "so calm there's almost no wind or weather there at all."<ref name=telegraph>Kenber, Billy. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/antarctica/6121866/Scientists-identify-coldest-place-on-earth.html "Scientists identify coldest place on earth"], ''[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]'', September 1, 2009. Accessed September 9, 2009.</ref> Ridge A is a low ridge of ice and has been estimated to have very low disturbances to visibility, such as thick atmospheric boundary layer, amount of water vapour and numerous others.
The site represents the "[[Eye (cyclone)|Eye of the Storm]]", whereby winds flowing off Antarctica in all directions appear to start from a point at Ridge A, where winds are at their calmest. It is also the site of a vortex in which swirling [[stratosphere|stratospheric]] winds high up and calm air at ground level combine to make it a place for viewing into space that is three times clearer than any other location on Earth.<ref name=BrisbaneTimes>Casey, Scott. [http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/technology/the-coldest-driest-place-in-the-world-20090902-f7uw.html "The coldest, driest place in the world"], ''[[Brisbane Times]]'', September 2, 2009. Accessed September 9, 2009.</ref>
Researchers{{Who|date=February 2011}} on the project suggested that photographs taken through a telescope at Ridge A could be nearly as good as those taken by the [[Hubble Space Telescope]]. Despite the difficult conditions on Antarctica and the remote location of Ridge A, construction costs for an observatory there that could match the Hubble telescope could be built at a fraction of the cost of sending Hubble into space.<ref name=BrisbaneTimes/>
For several years a second [[Giant Magellan Telescope]] in Antarctica has been proposed.<ref>{{Citation |last=Angel |first=Roger |last2=Lawrence |first2=Jon |last3=Storey |first3=John |year=2004 |title=Concept for a second Giant Magellan Telescope (GMT) in Antarctica |url=http://caao.as.arizona.edu/publications/GMT%20final%20fixes.pdf |format=PDF}}</ref>
==Observatory==
Since January 2012, a small international observatory, the [[High Elevation Antarctic Terahertz Telescope|High Elevation Antarctic Terahertz (HEAT) telescope]], has operated at Ridge A, jointly run by American and Australian researchers.<ref name="sims">{{citation |title = Where is Ridge A? |last=Sims |first=Geoff |last2=Kulesa |first2=Craig |last3=Ashley |first3=Michael C.B. |last4=Lawrence |first4=Jon S. |last5=Saunders |first5=Will |last6=Storey |first6=John W.V. |year=2012 |journal=Proc. SPIE 8444, Ground-based and Airborne Telescopes IV, 84445H |doi=10.1117/12.925512}}</ref> By virtue of the weather, this [[submillimetre astronomy|submillimetre]] or [[terahertz astronomy|terahertz]] telescope is capable of observing wavelengths of light that rarely make it through the atmosphere to the ground anywhere else on Earth.
==See also== *[[Dome A]] *[[List of optical telescopes]] *[[South Pole Telescope]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} This section provides an overview of the status of the [[right to food]] at a national level. ==Right to food in the world== [[File:Right to Food World Map-detailed.svg|thumb|center|750px| '''Framework law'''{{harvnb|Knuth|2011}}.
{{Legend|#6d009a|Adopted a framework law (10).}} {{Legend|#a25ccf|Drafting a framework law (9).}} '''Constitutional: explicit as right'''
{{Legend|#004098|As a separate and stand-alone right (9).}} {{Legend|#0380ae|Of a specific segment of the population (10).}} {{Legend|#21d0c6|As part of a human right to an adequate standard of living, quality of life, development, or right to work (5).}} '''Constitutional: implicit or as directive principle'''
{{Legend|#34a711|Implicit in broader rights (31).}} {{Legend|#89dc6f|Explicit directive principle (13).}} '''Applicable via international law'''
{{Legend|#d9bf2d|Direct applicability of [[International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights|ICESCR]], [[Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women|CEDAW]] and [[Convention on the Rights of the Child|CRC]] (95).}} {{Legend|#db6b11|Direct applicability of [[International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights|ICESCR]] and [[Convention on the Rights of the Child|CRC]] (2).}} {{Legend|#e39c12|Direct applicability of [[Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women|CEDAW]] and [[Convention on the Rights of the Child|CRC]] (5).}} '''Commitment via ICESCR'''{{harvnb|United Nations Treaty Collection|2012b}}{{harvnb|United Nations Treaty Collection|2012a}}
{{Legend|#771600|Ratified the [[Optional Protocol to the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights|Optional Protocol to the ICESCR]] (8).}} {{Legend|#c85f47|Ratified the [[International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights|ICESCR]] (160).}} {{Legend|#e0e0e0|No known right to food.}} Note: The same country can fall in multiple categories; the colour given to a country corresponds to the highest listed category in which a country falls.]] == Country by country == === Argentina === Argentina has included the topic of [[food sovereignty]] in framework law, though its status is sometimes controversial: Law 25.724 on the National Programme for Food and Nutrition Security, 2003.{{harvnb|Knuth|2011}}: 31. === Bangladesh === The right to food is enshrined in the constitution, Article 15 (Provision of basic necessities):
"It shall be a fundamental responsibility of the State to attain, through planned economic growth, a constant increase of productive forces and a steady improvement of the material and cultural standard of living of the people, with a view to securing to its citizens... the provision of the basic necessities of life, including food, clothing, shelter..."{{harvnb|Food and Agriculture Organization|1998}}.
In 2004, the Special Rapporteur leads a country mission to [[Bangladesh]].{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2004a}}. === Benin === In 2010, the Special Rapporteur leads a country mission to [[Benin]].{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2010e}}. === Bolivia === [[Bolivia]] has included the topic of food sovereignty in framework law, though its status is sometimes controversial: Supreme Decree No 28667 of 5 April 2006; Food Law for Workers, 2004.{{harvnb|Knuth|2011}}: 31. In 2007, the Special Rapporteur leads a country mission to Bolivia.{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2007a}}. === Brazil === The right to food is enshrined in the constitution, Article 227 (Right to food for children and teenagers):
"It is the duty of the family, of society, and of the State to ensure children and adolescents, with absolute priority, the right to life, health, food, education, leisure, professional training, culture, dignity, respect, freedom, and family and community life, in addition to safeguarding them against all forms of negligence, discrimination, exploitation, violence, cruelty, and oppression."{{harvnb|Food and Agriculture Organization|1998}}.
In 2003, the [[Fome Zero]] (Zero Hunger) government program is introduced by president Lula da Silva, with the objective to eradicate hunger and extreme poverty in [[Brazil]]. In 2003, the Special Rapporteur leads a country mission to Brazil.{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2003}}. In 2006, Brazil adopts a framework law on the right to food.{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2010a}} Brazil has included the topic of food sovereignty in framework law, though its status is sometimes controversial: Law No. 11,346, 2006 Establishing the National Food and Nutrition Security System (SISAN); Decree No. 6273, establishing the Interministerial Chamber for Food and Nutritional Security, 2007.{{harvnb|Knuth|2011}}: 31. In 2007, Brazil’s National Rapporteur on the Right to Food, Water, and Rural Land files a successful class action on behalf of [[favela]] residents.{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2010a}} In 2010, the Brazilian House of Representatives votes a Constitutional amendment on the right to food.{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2010a}} In 2010, the Special Rapporteur leads a country mission to Brazil.{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2010d}}. In 2012, the Special Rapporteur, Mr. De Schutter, pointed to the example of Brazil to highlight the effectiveness of multi-year national framework laws on the right to food.{{harvnb|De Schutter|2012}}. === Canada === In 2012, the Special Rapporteur leads a country mission to [[Canada]].{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2012f}}. === China === In 2012, the Special Rapporteur leads a country mission to [[China]].{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2012e}}. === Colombia === The right to food is enshrined in the [[Colombia]]n constitution, Article 44:
"The following are basic rights for children... a balanced diet..."{{harvnb|Food and Agriculture Organization|1998}}.
=== Congo === The right to food is enshrined in the constitution of the [[Republic of the Congo]], Article 34 (Health, Aged, Handicapped):
"The State is the guarantor of public health. Every citizen shall have the right to a level of life sufficient to assure his health, his well-being and that of his family, notably food, clothing, shelter, medical care as well as necessary social services."{{harvnb|Food and Agriculture Organization|1998}}.
=== Cuba === The right to food is enshrined in the constitution, Article 8 (The Socialist State):
"...as the power of the people and for the people, guarantees:... That no child be left without schooling, food and clothing."{{harvnb|Food and Agriculture Organization|1998}}.
In 2007, the Special Rapporteur leads a country mission to [[Cuba]].{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2007b}}. === Ecuador === The right to food is enshrined in the old constitution, Article 19:
"...The right to a standard of living that ensures the necessary health, food, clothing, housing, medical care and social services."{{harvnb|Food and Agriculture Organization|1998}}.
Ecuador has included the topic of food sovereignty in framework law, though its status is sometimes controversial: Law on Food and Nutritional Security, No. 41, 2006; Law on Food Sovereignty, Official Registry No. 583, 5 May 2009.{{harvnb|Knuth|2011}}: 31. In 2008, [[Ecuador]] includes the right to food in its [[2008 Constitution of Ecuador|Constitution]], approved on September 28 by 64% of the population in a referendum. Article 281, titled Food Sovereignty reads: "Food Sovereignty constitutes an objective and strategic obligation from the State to guarantee its people, communities, pueblos and nationalities self sufficiency in healthy food, culturally appropriate in a permanent form."{{harvnb|Pena|2008}}. In 2009, Ecuador develops a Food Sovereignty Framework Law.{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2010a}} === El Salvador === El Salvador has included the topic of food sovereignty in framework law, though its status is sometimes controversial: Decree 63 of 16 October 2009 which establishes the National Food and Nutrition Security Council (CONASAN). At present there are new drafts that update, replace or strengthen the existing legislation.{{harvnb|Knuth|2011}}: 31. === Ethiopia === The right to food is enshrined in the constitution, Article 90 (Social objectives):
"To the extent the country's resources permit, policies shall aim to provide all Ethiopians with access to public health and education, clean water, housing, food and social security."{{harvnb|Food and Agriculture Organization|1998}}.
In 2005, the Special Rapporteur leads a country mission to [[Ethiopia]].{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2005a}}. === Guatemala === The right to food is enshrined in the constitution, Article 51 (Protection of Minors and the Elderly):
"The State will protect the physical, mental and moral health of Minors and the Elderly. It will guarantee them their right to food, public health, education, security and social insurance."{{harvnb|Food and Agriculture Organization|1998}}.
And Article 99 (Feeding and nutrition):
"The State will see to it that the food and the nutrition of the population meet the minimum health requirements. The specialized actions among themselves or with international organizations dedicated to public health to achieve an effective national food delivery system."{{harvnb|Food and Agriculture Organization|1998}}.
In 2005, [[Guatemala]] adopts a framework law on the right to food.{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2010a}} Guatemala has included the topic of food sovereignty in framework law, though its status is sometimes controversial: Law on National Food and Nutrition Security System, Decree No. 32-2005, 2005. Agreement No 75/06, Regulation to the Law on National System on Food and Nutritional Security, 2006.{{harvnb|Knuth|2011}}: 31. In 2006, the Special Rapporteur leads a country mission to Guatemala.{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2006a}}. In 2010, the Special Rapporteur leads a country mission to Guatemala.{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2010c}}. === Haiti === The right to food is enshrined in the constitution, Article 22:
"The State recognizes the right of every citizen to decent housing, education, food and social security."{{harvnb|Food and Agriculture Organization|1998}}.
=== India === The right to food is enshrined in the constitution, Article 47 (Duty of the State to raise the level of nutrition and the standard of living and to improve public health):
"The State shall regard the raising of the level of nutrition and the standard of living of its people and the improvement of public health as among its primary duties and, in particular, the State shall endeavour to bring about prohibition of the consumption except for medicinal purpose of intoxicating drinks and of drugs which are injurious to health."{{harvnb|Food and Agriculture Organization|1998}}.
Fifty percent of the world’s hungry live in [[India]], with 200 million food-insecure people in 2008 according to the [[Food and Agriculture Organization|FAO]]. India ranks 66th out of 88 nations on the [[Global Hunger Index]].{{harvnb|Baski|2012}}. In 2001, India's Constitutional Court recognizes the right to food, transforming policy choices into enforceable rights.{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2010a}} The case started with a written petition submitted to the Supreme Court in April 2001 by the People's Union for Civil Liberties, Rajasthan, leading to prolonged public interest litigation.{{#tag:ref|People's Union for Civil Liberties vs Union of India and Others, Written Petition [Civil] 196 of 2001.|group=note}} Moreover, a larger public Right to Food Campaign is founded.{{harvnb|Right to Food Campaign|2012}}.{{#tag:ref|Sustained demands include: (1) a national Employment Guarantee Act, (2) universal mid-day meals in primary schools, (3) universalization of the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) for children under the age of six, (4) effective implementation of all nutrition-related schemes, (5) revival and universalization of the public distribution system, (6) social security arrangements for those who are not able to work, (7) equitable land rights and forest rights.|group=note}} In 2005, India adopts its [[Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act]] and the [[Right to Information Act, 2005|Right to Information Act]].{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2010a}} Between 20 August to 2 September of this year, the Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food leads a country mission to India.{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2006b}}. In 2011, the National Food Security Bill, 2011, popularly known as Right to Food Bill was proposed. In 2013, [[National Food Security Act, 2013]] was passed by the Indian Parliament. The Act guarantees subsidised food to 50% of the urban population and 75% of the rural population. The proposed legislation would provide of rice, wheat and coarse grain at very low prices to "priority households" similar to [[Below Poverty Line (India)|Below Poverty Line]] families. Distribution will be through the current [[Public Distribution System]], a government-run ration and fair price shops.{{harvnb|Baski|2012}}. Regarding India, the Special Rapporteur has commented:
"India provides one of the best examples in the world in terms of the justiciability of the right to food. The Constitution of India prohibits discrimination and recognizes all human rights. The right to life is recognized as a directly justiciable fundamental right (art. 21), while the right to food is defined as a directive principle of State policy (art. 47). As it has interpreted these provisions, the Supreme Court of India has found that the Government has a constitutional obligation to take steps to fight hunger and extreme poverty and to ensure a life with dignity for all individuals."{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2008}}: para. 67.
=== Indonesia === Indonesia has included the topic of food sovereignty in framework law, though its status is sometimes controversial: Food Act No. 7/1996 ; Regulation on Food Security No. 68/2002.{{harvnb|Knuth|2011}}: 31. === Iran === The right to food is enshrined in the constitution, Article 3 (State Goals):
"...The planning of a correct and just economic system, in accordance with Islamic criteria, in order to create welfare, eliminate poverty, and abolish all forms of deprivation with respect to food, housing, work, health care, and the provision of social insurance for all."{{harvnb|Food and Agriculture Organization|1998}}.
And in Article 43 (Principles):
"The economy of the Islamic Republic of Iran, with its objectives of achieving the economic independence of the society, uprooting poverty and deprivation, and fulfilling human needs in the process of development while preserving human liberty, is based on the following criteria: The provision of basic necessities for all citizens: housing, food, clothing hygiene, medical treatment, education, and the necessary facilities for the establishment of a family."{{harvnb|Food and Agriculture Organization|1998}}.
=== Lebanon === In 2006, the Special Rapporteur leads a country mission to [[Lebanon]].{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2006d}}. === Madagascar === In 2012, the Special Rapporteur leads a country mission to [[Madagascar]].{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2012b}}. === Malawi === The right to food is enshrined in the constitution, Article 13:
"The State shall actively promote the welfare and development of the people of Malawi by progressively adopting and implementing policies and legislation aimed at achieving the following goals: Nutrition: To achieve adequate nutrition for all in order to promote good health and self-sufficiency."{{harvnb|Food and Agriculture Organization|1998}}.
2009, [[Malawi]] finalises its draft Right to Food Bill (adoption is scheduled for 2010).{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2010a}} === Mali === In 2006, [[Mali]] adopts its Agricultural Policy Act.{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2010a}} === Mexico === In 2011, a constitutional reform establishes the right to food in [[Mexico]].{{harvnb|De Schutter|2012}}:par 4. The [[Chamber of Deputies of Mexico|Chamber of Deputies]] unanimously approved the reform. The State now has an obligation to guarantee the right to food (Art. 4) and to guarantee that the supply of basic foods suffices through rural development (Art. 27):
"Art. 4: Every person has the right to adequate food to maintain his or her wellbeing and physical, emotional and intellectual development. The State must guarantee this right."
"Art. 27, Clause XX: Sustainable and integral rural development . . . will also have among its objectives that the State guarantee sufficient and timely supply of basic foods as established by the law."{{harvnb|Acedo|2011}}.
In 2011, the Special Rapporteur releases an end of mission statement to his country mission to Mexico{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2011b}}. In 2012, the Special Rapporteur leads a country mission to Mexico.{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2012d}}. === Mongolia === In 2005, the Special Rapporteur leads a country mission to [[Mongolia]].{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2005b}}. === Mozambique === In 2009, [[Mozambique]] sets up a drafting Committee to elaborate a Right to Food Framework Law, which will submit a draft bill on the Right to Adequate Food to the government before the end of 2010.{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2010a}} === Nicaragua === The right to food is enshrined in the constitution, Article 63:
"It is the right of Nicaraguans to be protected against hunger. The State shall promote programmes which assure adequate availability and equitable distribution of food."{{harvnb|Food and Agriculture Organization|1998}}.
Nicaragua has included the topic of food sovereignty in framework law, though its status is sometimes controversial: Law on Food and Nutritional Sovereignty and Security, No. 163- 2009, Decree No. 03-2007, Reforms and Amendments to Decree No. 71-98; Regulation to the Law No. 290, Law on Organization and Competences, 2007. At present there are new drafts that update, replace or strengthen the existing legislation.{{harvnb|Knuth|2011}}: 31. In 2010, the Special Rapporteur leads a country mission to [[Nicaragua]].{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2010b}}. === Niger === In 2002, the Special Rapporteur leads a country mission to [[Niger]].{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2002}}. In 2006, the Special Rapporteur leads a country mission to Niger.{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2006c}}. === Nigeria === The right to food is enshrined in the constitution, Article 16:
"The State shall assure, within the context of the ideals and objectives for which provisions are made in this constitution,... that suitable and adequate shelter, suitable and adequate food, reasonable living wages, are provided for all citizens."{{harvnb|Food and Agriculture Organization|1998}}.
=== Nepal === In 2008, [[Nepal]]: A case on the right to food is filed in the Nepalese Constitutional Court, which issues an interim order for the immediate provision of food to hungry communities.{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2010a}} In 2009, Nepal includes the right to food sovereignty in its interim constitution.{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2010a}} === Nicaragua === In 2009 [[Nicaragua]] adopts a framework law on the right to food.{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2010a}} === Pakistan === The right to food is enshrined in the constitution, Article 38:
"The State shall provide basic necessities of life, such as food, clothing, housing, education and medical relief."{{harvnb|Food and Agriculture Organization|1998}}.
=== Paraguay === The right to food is enshrined in the constitution, Article 53 (Children):
"Every parent has the right and obligation to care for, to feed, to educate, and to support his children while they are minors. The laws will punish those parents who fail to comply with their duty to provide their children with food..."{{harvnb|Food and Agriculture Organization|1998}}.
=== Palestine, Occupied Territories === In 2004, the Special Rapporteur leads a country mission to [[Occupied Palestinian Territories]].{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2004b}}. === Peru === Peru has included the topic of food sovereignty in framework law, though its status is sometimes controversial: Decree No. 118-2002 PCM, establishing the Multisectoral Commission on Food Security, 2002; Decree No. 139/02/PCM, Conforming the Technical Committee of the Multisectoral Commission on Food Security, 2002. At present there are new drafts that update, replace or strengthen the existing legislation.{{harvnb|Knuth|2011}}: 31. === South Africa === In 1996, [[South Africa]] includes the right to food in its [[Chapter 2 of the Constitution of South Africa#Health care.2C food.2C water and social security|Constitution]] (Chapter 2, Section 27).{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2010a}} All social and economic rights are justiciable under South African law and the South African Bill of Rights, incorporated into the Constitution, explicitly provides every person the right to have access to sufficient food and water, subject to progressive realization.{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2008}}: para. 68. The right to food is enshrined in the constitution, Section 27 (Health care, food, water and social security):
"1) Everyone has the right to have access to: a) health care services, including reproductive health care; b) sufficient food and water; and c) social security, including, if they are unable to support themselves and their dependants, appropriate social assistance. 2)The state must take reasonable legislative and other measures, within its available resources, to achieve the progressive realization of each of these rights..."{{harvnb|Food and Agriculture Organization|1998}}.
And in Section 28 (Children):
"1) Every child has the right to: a) a name and a nationality from birth; b) family care or parental care, or to appropriate alternative care when removed from the family environment; c) basic nutrition, shelter, basic health care services and social services..."{{harvnb|Food and Agriculture Organization|1998}}.
In 2005, a case gets brought before the South African Equality Court demanding the protection of the livelihoods of traditional fishers.{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2010a}} In 2007, the Equality Court demands an alteration of the fishery policy to comply with the right to food.{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2010a}}; {{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2008}}: para. 68. In 2012, the Special Rapporteur leads a country mission to South Africa.{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2012c}}. === Sri Lanka === The right to food is enshrined in the constitution, Article 27:
"The State is pledged to establish in Sri Lanka a democratic socialist society, the objectives of which include... the realization by all citizens of an adequate standard of living for themselves and their families, including adequate food, clothing and housing..."{{harvnb|Food and Agriculture Organization|1998}}.
=== Syria === In 2011, the Special Rapporteur leads a country mission to [[Syria]].{{harvnb|Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food|2011a}}. === Uganda === The right to food is enshrined in the constitution, Objective 14 (General social and economic objectives):
"The State shall endeavour to fulfil the fundamental rights of all Ugandans to social justice and economic development and shall, in particular, ensure that... all Ugandans enjoy rights and opportunities and access to education, health services, clean and safe water, decent shelter, adequate clothing, food, security and pension and retirements benefits."{{harvnb|Food and Agriculture Organization|1998}}.
=== Ukraine === The right to food is enshrined in the constitution, Article 48:
"Everyone has the right to a standard of living sufficient for himself or herself, and his or her family that includes adequate nutrition, clothing and housing."{{harvnb|Food and Agriculture Organization|1998}}.
=== Venezuela === Venezuela has included the topic of food sovereignty in framework law, though its status is sometimes controversial: Organic Law on Agricultural and Food Security and Sovereignty, Decree No 6.071, 2008; Law establishing a Programme on Food for Workers, 1998; Law on Food for Workers, 2004; Decree No. 4.448, Regulation of the Law on Food for Workers, 2006.{{harvnb|Knuth|2011}}: {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2015}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Roger Kasperson | image = | image_size = 245px | residence = [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]] | nationality = [[United States]] | field = [[Risk]], [[Geography]] | institutions = [[Michigan State University]]
[[Clark University]]
[[University of Connecticut]]
[[National Academy of Sciences]]
[[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] | alma_mater = [[University of Chicago]]
[[Clark University]] | known_for = [[Risk Analysis]]
[[Risk Assessment]]
[[Risk perception]]
[[Social Amplification and Attenuation of Risk]] }} '''Roger Kasperson''' (born 1938) is an American risk analyst, a distinguished academic and professor at [[Clark University]] {{cite web|url=https://www.clarku.edu/faculty/facultybio.cfm?id=68|title=Roger Kasperson, PhD: Research Professor and Distinguished Scientist|author=Clark University|publisher=Clark University|date=30 September 2015|accessdate=30 September 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://thebulletin.org/bio/roger-e-kasperson|title=Roger Kasperson|author=Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists|publisher=Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists|date=1 May 2012|accessdate=30 September 2015}} and is one of the proponents of [[Risk perception]] studies with his work on The Social Amplification/Attentuation of Risk Framework (SARF).{{cite journal|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1539-6924.1988.tb01168.x/abstract|title=The Social Amplification of Risk: A Conceptual Framework|author= Kasperson, Roger E. |author2= Renn, Ortwin |author3= Slovic, Paul |author4= Brown, Halina S. |author5= Emel, Jacque |author6= Goble, Robert |author7= Kasperson, Jeanne X. |author8= Ratick, Samuel |journal=Risk Analysis|date=1988|accessdate=30 September 2015 |doi=10.1111/j.1539-6924.1988.tb01168.x |volume=8 |pages=177–187}}{{cite journal|url=http://paul-hadrien.info/backup/LSE/IS%20490/The%20social%20amplifciation%20and%20attenuation%20of%20risk.pdf|title=The Social Amplification and Attenuation of Risk|author1= Kasperson, Roger E. |author2= Kasperson, Jeanne X.|publisher=Sage Publications Inc. (in association with the American Academy of Political Science and Social Science)|date=May 1996|accessdate=30 September 2015}} Honored by the [[Association of American Geographers]] for his research on hazards,{{cite web|url=http://www.aag.org/cs/honors|title=Honors of the Association of American Geographers|author= [[Association of American Geographers]]|publisher=Association of American Geographers|date=1991|accessdate=30 September 2015}} he also served on various committees of the U.S. [[National Research Council (United States)|National Research Council]] (a.k.a., [[National Science Foundation]]) as well as the council of the [[Society for Risk Analysis]]{{cite web|url=http://www.geographie.uni-bonn.de/bilder-pressemitteilungen/kasperson|title=Closing the science/practice gap: exploring approaches to vulnerability and resilience|author= [[University of Bonn]]|publisher=University of Bonn|date=30 January 2014|accessdate=30 September 2015}} and was given the 2006 Distinguished Achievement Award of the SRA.{{cite web|url=http://www.sra.org/awards|title=Awards|author= [[Society for Risk Analysis]]|publisher=[[Society for Risk Analysis]]|date=2006|accessdate=30 September 2015}} He is an elected member of the [[National Academy of Sciences]] {{cite web|url=http://www.aag.org/cs/about_aag/grants_and_awards/aag_honors/other_honors_for_geographers|title=Geographer Members of the National Academy of Science|author= [[Association of American Geographers]]|publisher=Association of American Geographers|date=2004|accessdate=30 September 2015}} and served as executive director for the [[Stockholm Environment Institute]] 2000–2004.{{cite web|url=http://www.geographie.uni-bonn.de/bilder-pressemitteilungen/kasperson|title=Closing the science/practice gap: exploring approaches to vulnerability and resilience|author= [[University of Bonn]]|publisher=University of Bonn|date=30 January 2014|accessdate=30 September 2015}} ==See also== *[[Clark University]] *[[Society for Risk Analysis]] == External links == *[http://www.clarku.edu Clark University] *[http://sra.org/ Society for Risk Analysis] ==References== {{reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kasperson, Roger}} [[Category:Members of the United States National Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] [[Category:1938 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American geographers]]

'''Rudnicki''' (feminine: '''Rudnicka''') is a Polish-language [[toponymic surname]] derived from one of places named [[Rudnica (disambiguation)|Rudnica]]. The Russian-language equivalent is [[Rudnitsky]], Lithuanian: '''Rudnickis'''
It may refer to:
* [[Adolf Rudnicki]], Polish essayist * Icchak Rudnicki, birth name of [[Yitzhak Arad]], Israeli historian, former director of Yad Vashem * [[John Rudnicki]], American professor in engineering * [[Klemens Rudnicki]], Polish general * [[Konrad Rudnicki]], Polish astronomer *[[Lidia Rudnicka]], Polish-American dermatologist * [[Szymon Rudnicki]], Polish historian
* [[Lidia Rudnicka]], Polish-American professor, researcher and dermatologist *{{ill|Halina Rudnicka|pl}} Polish award-winning writer
==See also== *[[Edmond Roudnitska]]
{{surname}} [[category:Polish-language surnames]] [[category:toponymic surnames]]

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=November 2007}} {{Cossacks}} '''Stanitsa''' ({{lang-rus|стани́ца|p=stɐˈnʲitsə}}; {{lang-uk|станиця}}, ''stanytsia'') is a village inside a [[Cossacks|Cossack]] [[Cossack host|host]] (viysko) ({{lang|ru|казачье войско}}, ''kazachye voysko'', sometimes translated as "Cossack Army"). Stanitsas were the primary unit of Cossack hosts.
While the word ''stanitsa'' in a modern usage survives, the stanitsa system in its historic context was effectively destroyed in the aftermath of the Russian revolution, when the [[Russian Civil War|Civil War]] and subsequent [[Collectivisation in the USSR|collectivisation]] of the land by the state in the [[Joseph Stalin|Stalin]]ist period and [[Holodomor]] destroyed the culture and the economic foundations of stanitsas.
==Historical definition== Historically, the stanitsa was a unit of economic and political organisation of the Cossack peoples primarily in the southern regions of the [[Russian Empire]].
Much of the land was held in common by the stanitsa, subject to annual allocation to Cossack families by the [[Ataman]], the appointed leader of the community. This was a fully democratic, unique process, characteristic of Russia's South only. A similar democratic system was only used in Novgorod Republic, before its annexation by the Muscovite Tsardom.
==Modern usage== [[File:Map of Russia - Stanitsa.svg|thumb|left|Regions of Russia where stanitsa are a type of settlement]] In modern [[Russia]], stanitsas are classified as a type of [[types of inhabited localities in Russia|rural localities]] and are mostly predominant in the southern regions of [[Rostov Oblast]], [[Krasnodar Krai|Krasnodar]] and [[Stavropol Krai]]s and most of the Republics of the [[Northern Caucasus]].
{{clear left}}
[[Category:History of the Cossacks]] [[Category:Rural geography]] [[Category:Geography of Russia]] [[Category:Human habitats]] [[Category:Cossack culture]]
{{Russia-stub}} {{Ukraine-stub}}
