revision.text:
__NOTOC__ {{History of Colombia}} This is a [[timeline]] of events related to the [[Colombian armed conflict]].
''This timeline is '''incomplete'''; some important events may be missing. Please help add to it.''
==Background== Events that preceded the conflict.
===1899=== * [[Thousand Days War]], civil war between the two ruling parties [[Colombian Liberal Party]] and [[Colombian Conservative Party]], ===1902=== * End of Civil War. Tensions between parties remain. ===1928=== * [[Banana massacre]] in the town of [[Ciénaga, Magdalena|Cienaga]] by the [[Colombian Army]] after a workers' strike against the [[United Fruit Company]]. ===1948=== * Death of [[Jorge Eliecer Gaitan]] triggers [[Bogotazo|El Bogotazo]], Liberal and Conservative violence spread as part of [[La Violencia]]. ===1950s=== * [[Marquetalia Republic|Marquetalia]] and other enclaves created by radical Liberal and Communist guerrillas. ====1953==== * General [[Gustavo Rojas Pinilla]] seizes power and offers an amnesty to Liberal and Conservative fighters, most of whom demobilize. ====1958==== *[[National Front (Colombia)|The National Front]] created by the [[Colombian Liberal Party|Liberal]] and [[Colombian Conservative Party|Conservative]] parties, after mutual agreements and a December 1957 plebiscite. ====1959==== * U.S. President Eisenhower sent a survey team to Colombia to investigate the political situation in Colombia. As a result, the U.S. decided to help Colombia in counter-insurgency doctrines.<ref name="SOA Watch">[http://www.soaw.org/newswire_detail.php?id=1378 SOA Watch<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016190945/http://www.soaw.org//newswire_detail.php?id=1378 |date=2007-10-16 }}</ref>
==Colombian armed conflict==
===1960s=== ====1960==== * January 11 - Jacobo Prías aka "Charro Negro", Chief of the [[Communist Agrarian Movement]] is killed. The Colombian government is blamed.<ref>[http://www.farcep.org/aniversario/especial40aniv/textcrono.html FARC-EP timeline] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930160206/http://www.farcep.org/aniversario/especial40aniv/textcrono.html |date=2007-09-30 }}</ref> ====1961==== * Reports of helicopters were being deployed with US instructors accompanying Colombian pilots.<ref name="SOA Watch"/> ====1962==== * A United States special warfare team, trained in Kennedy's Counterinsurgency doctrine, and headed by Gen. William Yarborough, was sent to Colombia. Following this cycles of special warfare teams arrived in Colombia between 1962 and 1965 to continue training in counterinsurgency operations<ref>[http://infocollective.org/drugoilandwars.htm Peter Dale Scott Drugs, Oil, and War Rowman and Littlefield Publishers: Oxford 2003<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20070218112229/http://infocollective.org/drugoilandwars.htm |date=2007-02-18 }}</ref> * Colombian Army military offensive against Marquetalia fails to eliminate the enclave. ====1964==== * [[Operation Soberanía (Colombia)]], launched by the Colombian Army simultaneously with [[Operation Marquetalia]] in southern [[Tolima Department]]. ====1965==== * Radical Liberal and Communist guerrillas from Marquetalia created the [[Southern Bloc of the FARC-EP|Southern Bloc]] ====1966==== *Establishment of the [[Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia]] (FARC) by [[Jacobo Arenas]] and [[Manuel Marulanda]], among others.
===1970s=== ====1971==== *The FARC begin kidnapping as a major source of income.<ref name="Military.com - FARC activities">[http://www.military.com/Resources/ResourceFileView?file=FARC-Activities.htm Military.com - FARC activities]</ref> ====1975==== *FARC Kidnaps the [[Netherlands|Dutch]] consul in [[Cali]] Eric Leupin, demanding a US$1 million in ransom.<ref name="Military.com - FARC activities"/> ====1976==== *October - FARC Dutch consul hostage is released.<ref name="Military.com - FARC activities"/> ====1977==== *FARC Kidnaps a member of the United States [[Peace Corps]].
===1980s=== ====1980==== *[[Dominican embassy siege]] by [[19th of April Movement]] (M-19) ====1985==== *[[Palace of Justice siege]] by [[19th of April Movement]] (M-19) *[[Patriotic Union (Colombia)|Patriotic Union Party (UP)]]
===1990s=== ====1990==== *Colombian army launched [[Operation Centauro]] against the guerrillas with no significant results. ====1991==== *[[Operation Casa Verde]] launched by the Colombian army in an attempt to combat guerrillas concentrated in the area of [[Uribe, Meta|Uribe]], [[Meta Department|Meta]] with operations also extending to the [[Yarí Region|region of Yari]]. ====1996==== *June 16 - A confrontation for [[coca]] cultivations in [[Norte de Santander Department]] between the AUC paramilitaries and the FARC results in [[La Gabarra Massacre]]. ====1997==== *[[Operation Destructor]] launched by the Colombian army destroying numerous camp sites. According to the army there were 600 guerrilla casualties. *[[Mapiripán Massacre|Mapiripán Massacre (1997)]] ====1999==== *[[FARC-Government peace process (1999-2002)|FARC-Government peace process]] starts *FARC released a hostage held since 1977 (22 years) after a payment of a US$250,000 dollar ransom.
===2000s=== ====2002==== *[[Bojayá massacre|Bojayá massacre (2002)]] *[[Operation TH]] launched by the Colombian army to recover the [[El Caguan DMZ|former demilitirized zone]] after the failed [[FARC-Government peace process (1999-2002)|peace process]] between the [[Andrés Pastrana|Pastrana government]] and the [[FARC]] guerrilla. ====2004==== *[[Operation JM]] launched by the Colombian army, first of operation part of [[Plan Patriota]]. ====2006==== *[[2006–2007 Colombian parapolitics scandal|Parapolitics scandal]] broke out. ====2008==== *[[Operation Emmanuel|A humanitarian exchange of important hostages]] and [[Operation Jaque|the rescue of 15 important hostages, including three Americans and Íngrid Betancourt.]]
===2010s=== ====2010==== * January 1 - 18 FARC rebels are killed in a raid by the Colombian Air Force in the south while celebrating the New Year.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/americas/2010/01/201011235131565705.html |title=Colombian forces raid Farc camp}}</ref>
====2011==== {{Expand section|date=February 2018}}
====2012==== {{Expand section|date=February 2018}}
====2013==== * '''1 January''' – The Colombian military kills 13 FARC rebels in an airstrike.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-20884906 |title=Thirteen Colombian Farc rebels 'killed in air strike'}}</ref> * '''22 January''' – FARC rebels have blown up two southern oil pipelines with dynamite and planted a bomb on the top coal exporter's northern railway after the end of a ceasefire.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/colombia-rebels-energy/colombia-says-farc-rebels-hit-two-oil-pipelines-coal-rail-line-idUSL1N0AR6V620130122 |title=Colombia says FARC rebels hit two oil pipelines, coal rail line}}</ref> * '''9 November''' – A gunman opens fire on a bar in [[Cali]] and kills eight people.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-colombia-shooting-bar/gunman-kills-eight-in-bar-in-cali-colombia-idUSBRE9A80CY20131109 |title=Gunman kills eight in bar in Cali, Colombia}}</ref>
====2014==== {{Expand section|date=February 2018}}
====2015==== {{Expand section|date=February 2018}}
====2016==== {{Expand section|date=February 2018}}
====2017==== {{Expand section|date=February 2018}}
====2018====
* '''5 January''' – Two encounters happened in southwestern Colombia, leaving at least 7 people killed. During the incident a rebeld leader was shot dead.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.wradio.com.co/noticias/internacional/enfrentamientos-entre-bandas-ilegales-dejan-7-muertos-en-suroeste-de-colombia/20180105/nota/3681772.aspx|title=Enfrentamientos entre bandas ilegales dejan al menos 7 muertos en el suroeste de Colombia|website=W Radio|date=5 January 2018|accessdate=17 June 2018|language=es}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.noticiasrcn.com/nacional-pais/seis-personas-muertas-deja-enfrentamiento-bandas-criminales-bolivar-cauca|title=Seis personas muertas deja enfrentamiento de bandas criminales en Bolívar, Cauca |website=Noticias RCN|date=5 January 2018|accessdate=17 June 2018|language=es}}</ref>
* '''10 January''' – A Colombian soldier was shot dead by a ELN sniper in the department of Arauca.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://m.eltiempo.com/colombia/otras-ciudades/soldado-es-asesinado-por-francotirador-del-eln-en-arauca-169748|title=Militar fue asesinado por un francotirador del Eln, en vía de Arauca|website=El Tiempo|date=10 January 2018|accessdate=1 March 2018|language=es}}</ref>
* '''13 January''' – Militants of the ELN kidnapped a contractor of Ecopetrolun in the Departament of Arauca.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://caracol.com.co/radio/2018/01/13/regional/1515855566_735409.html|title=Eln secuestra a contratista de la empresa Ecopetrol en Saravena, Arauca|website=Caracol Radio|date=13 January 2018|accessdate=1 March 2018|language=es}}</ref>
* '''19 January''' – Uniformed soldiers who were in an army base in the municipality of Teorama, Norte de Santander, were attacked in an unexpected attack by members of the ELN guerrillas. One soldier was killed and two more were injured.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.co/colombia/nuevo-ataque-del-eln-deja-un-soldado-muerto-y-dos-mas-heridos-270379|title=Nuevo ataque del ELN deja un soldado muerto y dos más heridos|website=El Universal Cartagena|date=19 January 2018|accessdate=1 March 2018|language=es}}</ref>
* '''21 January''' – A caravan made up of members of the National Protection Unit, along with members of the FARC political party, who were returning from a meeting in the village of El Oasis, was attacked by gunfire in the department of Arauca. One of the vehicles that was part of the caravan was incinerated and a civilian who was part of an oil company in the sector was killed in the attack.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.lafm.com.co/nacional/atentado-contra-militantes-del-partido-de-las-farc-en-arauca/|title=Atentan contra militantes del partido de las Farc en Arauca|website=La FM|date=21 January 2018|accessdate=1 March 2018|language=es}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.co/colombia/farc-denuncia-ataque-armado-en-arauca-270532|title=Farc denuncia ataque armado en Arauca|website=El Universal Cartagena|date=21 January 2018|accessdate=1 March 2018|language=es}}</ref>
* '''27 January''' – ** At least five police officers were killed and 42 others injured in a bombing attack that targeted a police station in the northern coastal city of Barranquilla.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://aa.com.tr/en/americas/colombia-bombing-kills-at-least-5-police-officers-/1044547|title=Colombia: Bombing kills at least 5 police officers|website=Anadolu Agency|date=28 January 2018|accessdate=1 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.portafolio.co/economia/el-eln-se-atribuyo-el-atentado-de-este-sabado-en-barranquilla-513698|title=El ELN se atribuyó el atentado de este sábado en Barranquilla|website=Portafolio|date=28 January 2018|accessdate=1 March 2018|language=es}}</ref> ** In the town of Buenavista, Santa Rosa del Sur, an explosive device was hurled against the police substation in that area. The incident left two police officers dead and one injured.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.rcnradio.com/locales/dos-policias-muertos-y-un-herido-tras-atentado-contra-estacion-de-policia-en-santa-rosa-del-sur/|title=Dos policías muertos y un herido tras atentado contra estación de Policía en Santa Rosa del Sur|website=RCN Radio|date=28 January 2018|accessdate=1 March 2018|language=es}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.elespectador.com/noticias/judicial/mindefensa-atribuye-eln-autoria-de-atentados-en-barranquilla-soledad-y-santa-rosa-articulo-735985|title=Mindefensa atribuye al Eln atentados en Barranquilla, Soledad y Santa Rosa|website=El Espectador|date=29 January 2018|accessdate=1 March 2018|language=es}}</ref> ** 28 people were injured in an attack on a police station in San Lorenzo, in Northern Ecuador.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.europapress.es/internacional/noticia-menos-13-policias-heridos-caracter-leve-atentado-contra-comisaria-norte-ecuador-20180127164232.html|title=Al menos 13 policías heridos de carácter leve por un atentado contra una comisaría del norte de Ecuador|website=Europa Press|date=27 January 2018|accessdate=1 March 2018|language=es}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ecuador-colombia-blast/ecuador-links-police-barracks-bombing-to-colombia-farc-dissidents-idUSKBN1FI2H4|title=Ecuador links police barracks bombing to Colombia FARC dissidents|website=Reuters|date=29 January 2018|accessdate=1 March 2018}}</ref>
* '''28 January''' – At least five people were injured in an attack against the police in the metropolitan area of the Colombian city of Barranquilla.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://globovision.com/article/nuevo-ataque-contra-la-policia-en-colombia-deja-cinco-heridos|title=Nuevo ataque contra la Policía en Colombia deja cinco heridos|website=Globovisión|date=28 January 2018|accessdate=1 March 2018|language=es}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://caracol.com.co/programa/2018/01/29/6am_hoy_por_hoy/1517230056_481826.html|title=Eln es autor de atentados en Barranquilla, Soledad y Santa Rosa: Mindefensa|website=Caracol Radio|date=29 January 2018|accessdate=1 March 2018|language=es}}</ref>
* '''3 February''' – FARC dissidents blew up an energy tower in the southeastern Colombian department of Guaviare, which left some 22,000 people in the area without electricity.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.elespectador.com/economia/atentado-contra-torre-de-energia-en-guaviare-deja-sin-luz-medio-departamento-articulo-737162|title=Atentado contra torre de energía en Guaviare deja sin luz a medio departamento|website=El Espectador|date=4 February 2018|accessdate=4 March 2018|language=es}}</ref>
* '''4 February''' – Armed men threw a grenade at a house in Ituango and fired repeatedly at its facade. The incident left a 3-year-old girl dead.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/colombia/medellin/antioquia-ataque-con-granada-en-una-vivienda-de-ituango-deja-una-bebe-muerta-178990|title=Ataque con granada en Ituango (Antioquia) dejó una bebé muerta|website=El Tiempo|date=5 February 2018|accessdate=5 February 2018|language=es}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://noticias.caracoltv.com/medellin/nina-de-dos-anos-fallece-tras-atentado-con-granada-en-una-casa-de-ituango-antioquia|title=Niña de dos años fallece tras atentado con granada en una casa de Ituango, Antioquia|website=Noticias Caracol|date=5 February 2018|accessdate=1 March 2018|language=es}}</ref>
* '''10 February''' – The National Liberation Army (ELN) activated explosive charges that damaged a bridge and road in the department of Cesar (north), leaving no victims.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://m.excelsior.com.mx/global/2018/02/10/1219432|title=ELN inicia 'paro armado' en Colombia con dos bombazos|date=10 February 2018|website=Excelsior|accessdate=17 June 2018|language=es}}</ref>
* '''12 February''' – ** Colombian soldier Jhon Jairo Delgado Bastidas was killed by guerrillas of the National Liberation Army (ELN) in the municipality of Valdivia, in the department of Antioquia.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://noticiasvenezuela.org/2018/02/12/el-eln-asesina-a-un-soldado-colombiano-en-el-tercer-dia-de-paro-armado/|title=El ELN asesina a un soldado colombiano en el tercer día de paro armado|website=Noticias Venezuela|date=12 February 2018|accessdate=4 March 2018|language=es}}</ref> ** The railway line of Colombia's largest coal mine, Cerrejón, was attacked with explosives that caused the suspension of trains without affecting production or exports.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.swissinfo.ch/spa/ataque-explosivo-paraliza-l%C3%ADnea-f%C3%A9rrea-de-minera-cerrej%C3%B3n-en-colombia/43897362|title=Ataque explosivo paraliza línea férrea de minera Cerrejón en Colombia|website=Swissinfo|date=13 February 2018|accessdate=4 March 2018|language=fr}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.elespectador.com/noticias/nacional/atentan-contra-tramo-de-la-linea-ferrea-del-cerrejon-en-la-guajira-articulo-738833|title=Atentan contra tramo de la línea férrea del Cerrejón en La Guajira|website=El Espectador|date=13 February 2018|accessdate=4 March 2018|language=es}}</ref>
* '''13 February''' – A dead policeman, identified as mayor Jorge Sáenz Animero, and three civilians injured, is the result of an attack perpetrated by armed men in the capital of Arauca.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/justicia/conflicto-y-narcotrafico/asesinado-policia-en-arauca-182154|title=Señalan al Eln de realizar 'plan pistola' tras asesinato de policía|website=El Tiempo|date=13 February 2018|accessdate=4 March 2018|language=es}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.colombia.com/actualidad/nacionales/arauca-dos-hombres-asesinaron-a-un-policia-y-dejaron-tres-personas-heridas-179493|title=Arauca: Dos hombres asesinaron a un policía y dejaron tres personas heridas|website=Colombia|date=13 February 2018|accessdate=4 March 2018|language=es}}</ref>
* '''16 February''' – A bomb exploded in the Paloquemao sector of Bogotá. The attack did not leave people injured.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.elespectador.com/noticias/nacional/con-bomba-panfletaria-en-bogota-continuan-ataques-del-eln-articulo-739496|title=Con bomba panfletaria en Bogotá, continúan ataques del Eln|website=El Espectador|date=16 February 2018|accessdate=4 March 2018|language=es}}</ref>
* '''19 February''' – Two soldiers were injured in an attack by dissidents of the former Colombian FARC guerrilla against Ecuadorian soldiers on the border with Colombia.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.eluniverso.com/noticias/2018/02/20/nota/6632272/dos-soldados-ecuatorianos-heridos-tras-ataque-disidentes-farc|title=Dos soldados ecuatorianos heridos tras ataque de disidentes de las FARC|website=El Universo|date=20 February 2018|accessdate=4 March 2018|language=es}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.elcomercio.com/actualidad/militares-atacados-disidentes-farc-mortero.html|title=Militares fueron atacados por disidentes de las FARC con un mortero artesanal|website=El Comercio|date=20 February 2018|accessdate=4 March 2018|language=es}}</ref>
* '''21 February''' – At least seven peasants were injured as they crossed a minefield mined by the extinct Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) guerrilla when they were carrying out coca leaf plantation removal work in the Nukak natural park in the Colombian department of Guaviare.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://confidencialcolombia.com/actualidad/siete-erradicarores-resultaron-heridos-al-caer-en-campo-minado-de-las-farc/|title=Siete erradicarores resultaron heridos tras caer en campo minado de las Farc|website=Confidencial Colombia|date=22 February 2018|accessdate=4 March 2018|language=es}}</ref>

Noticias Venezuela|date=25 February 2018|accessdate=4 March 2018|language=es}}</ref>
* '''27 February''' – At least five soldiers were killed and 13 wounded in a bomb attack against a Colombian army caravan in a rural area of the city of Cucuta, bordering Venezuela.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.noticiasdevenezuela.org/2018/02/27/cinco-militares-colombianos-muertos-en-emboscada-en-cucuta/|title=Cinco militares muertos en emboscada al Ejército en Norte de Santander|website=Noticias Venezuela|date=27 February 2018|accessdate=4 March 2018|language=es}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://caracol.com.co/emisora/2018/02/27/cucuta/1519723616_502480.html|title=Cinco militares muertos en emboscada al Ejército en Norte de Santander|website=Caracol Radio|date=27 February 2018|accessdate=4 March 2018|language=es}}</ref>
* '''28 February''' – A new assault by the ELN with gunfire and cylinder bombs, which was registered in the rural area of Convención, killed one soldier and injured four others.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/colombia/otras-ciudades/nuevo-ataque-del-eln-dejo-un-soldado-muerto-en-norte-de-santander-188500|title=Nuevo ataque del Eln dejó un soldado muerto y tres más heridos|last=Tiempo|first=Casa Editorial El|website=El Tiempo|date=1 March 2018|accessdate=4 March 2018|language=es}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.wradio.com.co/noticias/regionales/eln-es-el-responsable-de-ataque-en-el-municipio-de-convencion/20180301/nota/3717723.aspx|title=Eln es el responsable de ataque en el municipio de Convención|website=Wradio|date=1 March 2018|accessdate=4 March 2018|language=es}}</ref>
* '''1 March''' – An ELN attack killed 2 soldiers and 3 others were injured in [[Convención]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.radionacional.co/noticia/dialogos-eln/dos-soldados-muertos-tres-heridos-dejaron-taques-del-eln|title=Dos soldados muertos y tres heridos dejaron ataques del Eln|website=Radio Nacional de España|date=1 March 2018|accessdate=20 June 2018|language=es}}</ref>
* '''3 March''' – Two policemen were killed in an attack with explosives on the road from Caldono to Siberia in the department of Cauca.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rcnradio.com/colombia/sur/dos-policias-muertos-en-ataque-con-explosivos-en-caldono-cauca|title=Dos policías muertos en ataque con explosivos en Caldono, Cauca|website=RCN Radio|date=3 March 2018|accessdate=4 March 2018|language=es}}</ref>

{{other people}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox scientist |name = William Roy |image = |birth_date = 4 May 1726 |birth_place = [[Carluke]], [[Scotland]] |death_date={{death date and age|df=yes|1790|7|1|1726|5|4}} |death_place = London, England |nationality = [[Kingdom of Great Britain|British]] ([[Scotland|Scottish]]) |field = [[Surveying]] |known_for = The survey of Scotland. The survey linking Britain and France. |prizes = [[Copley Medal]] (1785) }}
[[Major-General]] '''William Roy''' [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]], [[Society of Antiquaries of London|FSA]] [[FRSE]] (4 May 1726 – 1 July 1790) was a [[Scotland|Scottish]] [[military engineer]], [[Surveyor (surveying)|surveyor]], and [[antiquarian]]. He was an innovator who applied new scientific discoveries and newly emerging technologies to the accurate [[Geodesy|geodetic]] mapping of Great Britain. His masterpiece is usually referred to as '''Roy's Map of Scotland'''.<ref>http://maps.nls.uk/geo/roy/#zoom=7&lat=56.8860&lon=-4.0709&layers=roy-highlands</ref>
It was Roy's advocacy and leadership that led to the creation of the [[Ordnance Survey]] in 1791, the year after his death. His technical work in the establishment of a [[baseline (surveying)|surveying baseline]] won him the [[Copley Medal]] in 1785. His maps and drawings of [[Roman Britain|Roman]] archaeological sites in [[Scotland]] were the first accurate and systematic study of the subject, and have not been improved upon even today. Roy was a fellow of the [[Royal Society]] and a member of the [[Society of Antiquaries of London]].
==Life and works==
===Principal sources=== * {{harvtxt|Lee|1885–1900}} Dictionary of National Biography (1900 edition). * {{harvtxt|Close|1969}} The early years of the Ordnance Survey. First published in 1924. Includes some of Roy's letters. * {{harvtxt|Hewitt|2011}} Map of a Nation: a biography of the Ordnance Survey. * {{harvtxt|Owen|Pilbeam|1992}} Ordnance Survey, map makers to Britain since 1791. Available online. * {{harvtxt|Seymour|1980}} A History of the Ordnance Survey. The ''official'' account. References to original papers. Available online. * {{harvtxt|Porter| 1889}} History of the Corps of Royal Engineers. Available online.
=== Early life and family === Roy was born at Milton Head in [[Carluke]] parish in [[South Lanarkshire]] on 4 May 1726.<ref name=dnb>{{harvtxt|Lee|1885–1900}} Dictionary of National Biography.</ref> His father was a [[Factor (Scotland)|factor]]<ref>A ''factor'' in Scotland is a representative of a landowner with the responsibilities of an estate manager.</ref> in the service of the Gordons/Hamiltons of Hallcraig, as well as an elder of the [[Church of Scotland|Kirk]]. His grandfather had held a similar position as factor, and his uncle acted in that capacity for the [[Lockharts of Lee]]. Thus Roy grew up in an environment where making land surveys and using maps was part of the daily business. He was educated in Carluke parish school and then [[Lanark Grammar School]].<ref name=rankin> {{Harvcolnb|Rankin|1874}} The Parish of Carluke, 1288 –1874 </ref> There is no record of a further education such as that enjoyed by his younger brother James.<ref>James Roy had held the bursary in the Grammar School and College of Glasgow, took a Master of Arts after studies in the Languages and Philosophy, was licensed by the Presbytery of Glasgow, and held several other notable positions before his untimely death in 1767, at the age of 37.{{Harv|Rankin|1874}} </ref>
The next few years of his life are poorly documented. Owen and Pilbeam claim<ref name=owenpilbeam> {{harvtxt|Owen|Pilbeam|1992}} Ordnance Survey, map makers to Britain since 1791, Chapter 1, pages 3–11 is devoted to Roy. </ref> that "Some time after 1738 (when Roy was 12) he moved to [[Edinburgh]] and gained experience of surveying and making plans, probably as a civilian draughtsman at the office of the Board of Ordnance at [[Edinburgh Castle]]." It is possible that he may have been employed there as a boy because it was normal procedure for the board to employ "cadets" aged ten or eleven who were trained to become civilian surveyors and draughtsmen. Roy was certainly associated with the board by 1746 (aged 20), for he was the author of an official map of [[Battle of Culloden|Culloden]] made soon after the battle.<ref name=seymour> {{harvcolnb|Seymour|1980}} A History of the Ordnance Survey. The material on Roy is in pages 3–9 for the Military Survey, pages13–18 for the Hounslow base, pages 33–37 for the calculation of the [[Anglo-French Survey (1784–1790)|Anglo-French Survey]] and pages 363–365 for his Instructions to Surveyors.</ref>
As an employee of the board he would have come to notice of Lieutenant-Colonel David Watson,<ref name=dnb/> Deputy Quartermaster-General of the Military District of [[North Britain]] for the board, whose headquarters was in Edinburgh. The terms of Roy's employment are unknown but must have some opportunity to undertake private surveys for he was reported as a respected land surveyor employed by the Callander family at their Craigforth estate near [[Stirling]] prior to his work for the military.<ref name=campbell> {{Harvcolnb|Campbell|1832|p=32}} ''Memoirs of James Campbell of Ardkinglass'',</ref>
Roy maintained his connections to his birthplace and the people living there. A servant for the Lockharts of Lee recalled his visits there over time, as his national reputation grew. She noted that at first he would dine in the servants hall, in later years he would dine with the family, and later still he would be seated at the right hand of the [[Laird]].<ref name="rankin"/>
==Roy as surveyor and soldier==
===The survey of Scotland=== [[Image:Mansewood1747-1755.jpg|thumb|right|350px|Detail (Pollokshaws, now in Glasgow) from a map in Roy's Military Survey of Scotland.<ref name=roymap/>]] In 1747 Lieutenant-Colonel David Watson, Deputy Quartermaster-General, proposed the compilation of a map of the [[Scottish Highlands]] to facilitate the subjugation of the [[Scottish clan|clan]]s following the [[Jacobitism|Jacobite]] [[Jacobite rising of 1745|rising of 1745]].<ref>{{Harvcolnb|Porter|1889}} ''History of the Royal Engineers'', Vol. I, Chapter 8, pp. 167–199 covers the period 1743–1763. </ref> In response, King [[George II of Great Britain|George II]] commissioned a military survey of the Highlands, and Watson was placed in charge, under the command of the [[Prince William, Duke of Cumberland|Duke of Cumberland]], but it fell to Roy "to begin, and afterwards to have a considerable share in, the execution of that map",<ref name=roy85quote> Quotation from {{harvtxt|Roy|1785}}, The account of the Hounslow baseline </ref> now known as ''The Duke of Cumberland's Map''.
Roy was without any military rank at this time<ref> Some sources wrongly attribute military rank or regiment to Roy in 1746: the obituary of {{Harvtxt|Burke|1793}}, page 212, states that Roy held the rank of colonel of artillery; a book by {{Harvtxt|Irving|1885}}, page 242, also has him as an army Colonel. Neither was Roy the nephew of David Watson as claimed by {{Harvtxt|Porter|1889}} in Volume 2 (page 229) of his history; Porter also quotes General Wolfe for the same error (page 388). {{harvtxt|Rankin|1784}} has him a Deputy Quartermaster General of the Survey in 1746. </ref> but Watson appointed him as an assistant to the quartermaster to provide him some seniority over the group of (typically) six soldiers who travelled with him: an NCO, two end markers, two chainmen and a batman.<ref name=owenpilbeam/> From 1749 he was joined by another five junior surveyors for various periods of time: notable among these young assistants were [[Paul Sandby]] (born 1731), later renowned for his watercolour landscapes, and a seventeen-year-old [[David Dundas (British Army officer)|David Dundas]] (born 1735), later Commander-in-Chief of the armed forces.<ref name=dnb/>
Eventually there were six teams conducting surveys by traverses of the country with the objects to the side of the line recorded by sketches and compass directions. The Highlands were covered by 1752, but the survey was extended to the lowlands for another three years, until 1755, when most of the engineer surveyors were posted to war stations. In the introduction to the 1885 account of the measurement of the Hounslow baseline Roy writes that the map remained "in an unfinished state ... and is to be considered as a magnificent military sketch rather than a very accurate map of a country ... (and) it would have been completed, and many of its imperfections no doubt remedied, but for the breaking out of war in 1755."<ref name=roy85quote/> The eighty-four original field sheets and the thirty-eight divisions of the "fair-protraction"are held in the [[British Museum]] together with a small index map and a reduced map of the whole country in a single sheet published as "the King's map". It is now possible to view the map online.<ref name=roymap> [http://maps.nls.uk/roy/index.html Roy's map] is held in the [[British Museum]] but it is available online by courtesy of the [[National Library of Scotland]]. The index page links to several views of the map including one in which it can be superimposed on the modern map.</ref>
===Military appointments=== Throughout the Survey of Scotland, Roy was a civilian assistant to David Watson the deputy quartermaster-general, but in 1755 the survey was terminated by the outbreak of the [[Seven Years' War]] with France and the consequent redeployment of personnel to more pressing posts in both the regular army and the [[Board of Ordnance]]. In the same year the engineers of the board were formed into the [[Royal Engineers|Corps of Engineers]]. The board officers were members of both structures, for they would be deployed with the army regiments for specialist duties.
In 1776 Roy was commissioned as a lieutenant in the [[53rd Foot]], a new regiment formed in 1755. At the same time he was appointed as a practitioner-engineer, the lowest rank in the Board of Ordnance survey department, and ensign in the Corps of Engineers.<ref> {{Harvcolnb|Porter|1889}} ''History of the Royal Engineers'', vol. II, Part 2, Chapter 1, pp. 88–100 covers the structure of the Board of Ordnance. </ref><ref> {{harvnb|Anderson|2010}}, Chapter 3, gives full details of the structure of the Board of Ordnance at the time of Roy. This thesis also contains many excellent images of maps and plans from the survey in the period. </ref> Thereafter Roy was promoted steadily, and rapidly, in both structures, but his army rank was always greater than his board rank. For example, he was lieutenant-colonel in the army by 1762 and director and lieutenant-colonel of the Engineers in 1783. He is best known by his army rank of major-general, which he attained in 1781.<ref> {{harvnb|Close|1924}}, p. 4, and {{harvtxt|Rankin|1784}}, online, give a details of Roy's promotions. </ref>
===Active service=== On the termination of the Scottish survey Roy, now under the jurisdiction of two military bodies, was posted in 1756 to the South of England where he was engaged, together with Watson and Dundas, in inspecting the readiness of coastal military installations in preparation for an expected French invasion. This work involved Roy in the production of plans of fortifications and rough maps of stretches of the south coast: examples are a sketch of the country from Gloucester to Pembroke, with Milford Haven and a sketch of the country betwixt Guildford and Canterbury. These sketches are preserved in the [[British Library]].
By 1757 Roy was with his regiment in France for the Rochefort expedition and then in Germany for the [[Battle of Minden]] in 1759. His technical abilities and willingness to innovate brought him to the favourable attention of his commanders. Preparatory to the battle, the various military engineers made drawings of each step of the coming battle, with each step drawn on a different sheet of paper. The commander could then study the course of the battle before it occurred, going from one sheet to the next. Lieutenant Roy, however, made his drawings on a single sheet with coordinated and accurate overlays, so that the commander could more easily study the course of the battle by examining a single sheet of paper. The commander's comprehension was greatly facilitated, and Roy's methodology was soon adopted as an advancement in military science.<ref name=campbell/> Thereafter his promotion was rapid, and by the end of the war in 1763 Roy was a lieutenant colonel in the regiment and director of the engineers of the Board of Ordnance as well as being the deputy quartermaster general for Germany.
===Surveyor-general=== [[File:Major-general-william-roy blue plaque.jpg|thumb|Blue plaque at Roy's London home, 10 Argyll Street.]] At the conclusion of the war in 1763 Roy returned to London, where he was based for the rest of his life. The threatened French invasion of the south coast had never materialised, but he felt strongly that the reconnaissances he had made with Watson at the outbreak of the war should be extended to a national survey, not just of the vulnerable south but the whole of the British Isles. He never ceased to champion this cause, but the expense of the [[Seven Years' War]] and then the [[American War of Independence]] excluded any expenditure on trigonometrical surveys for another twenty years.
In 1765 he was appointed surveyor-general under a royal warrant which directed him "to inspect, survey and make reports from time to time of the state of the coasts of this Kingdom and the islands thereunto belonging." This work, which took him to many parts of Britain and abroad (Ireland and [[Gibraltar]]), is recorded in the many plans and sketch maps of districts that are now lodged at the [[British Library]].
Despite the travel Roy was able to enter fully into the intellectual life of London, and in 1767 he became a fellow of the [[Royal Society]]. The only paper he read before the society was in 1783 on ''Rules for measuring heights with a barometer''. Roy was promoted to colonel in 1777, and to major-general in 1781. He was in charge of the departments of the Quartermaster-General and Chief Engineer in 1782, and in 1783 became the director of Royal Engineers.
===The Anglo-French survey=== {{main|Anglo-French Survey (1784–1790)}} Late in life, when he was 57, Roy was granted the opportunity to establish his lasting reputation in the world of geodesy. The opening came from a completely unexpected direction. In 1783 the [[Dominique, comte de Cassini|Comte de Cassini]] addressed a memoir to the Royal Society in which he expressed grave reservations of the measurements of latitude and longitude which had been undertaken at [[Royal Greenwich Observatory|Greenwich Observatory]]. He suggested that the correct values might be found by combining the [[Paris Observatory]] figures with a precise [[trigonometric]] survey between the two observatories.<ref> {{harvcolnb|Maskelyne|1787}} includes Cassini's memoir (in French) and his rebuttal. </ref> Sir [[Joseph Banks]], president of the [[Royal Society]], proposed that Roy should lead the project. Roy accepted with enthusiasm for he saw that apart from the specific measurements proposed the survey could be the first step towards the national survey that he had advocated so often. The whole project is described by Roy in three major contributions to the [[Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society]] in 1785,<ref name=roy1785>{{Harvcolnb|Roy|1785}} The measurement of the Hounslow baseline.</ref> 1787<ref name=roy1787>{{harvcolnb|Roy|1787}} Proposals for the triangulation</ref> and 1790.<ref name=roy1790>{{harvcolnb|Roy|1790}} Account of the triangulation and the calculations involved. </ref> There are shorter accounts of the project in the ''History of the Royal Engineers'',<ref> {{harvtxt|Porter|1889}} ''History of the Corps of Royal Engineers'' Part III, Chapter II, pages 228–255. </ref> the records of the Royal Society<ref> {{harvnb|Martin|McConnell|2008}} Notes and Records of the Royal Society</ref> and in every history of the Ordnance Survey.<ref> For the history of the Ordnance Survey see {{harvtxt|Seymour|1980}}, {{harvtxt|Owen|Pilbeam|1992}}.</ref>
[[File:Cannon in Roy Grove Hampton.jpg|thumb|Cannon in Roy Grove, Hampton marking the Hampton end of the first baseline of the triangulation of Great Britain]] After a preliminary survey by Roy and three other members of the Society on 16 April, they found a suitable location for the starting baseline on [[Hounslow|Hounslow Heath]], between King's Arbour and [[Hampton, London|Hampton]] Poor-house just over 5 miles to the south-east. A preliminary measurement of the line was carried out with a steel chain prepared by [[Jesse Ramsden]]. It was the intention to measure more accurately with a set of three deal rods about 20 ft. in length but their use had to be abandoned because of their susceptibility to lengthen and shorten in wet weather. The deal rods were replaced by one-inch-thick glass tubes of the same length. The final measurement gives the length of the base as 27404.7 ft. to an accuracy of about 3 inches in 5 miles (or about 1/100,000). The precision of this baseline measurement far exceeded any previous attempts, and in recognition Roy was awarded the [[Copley medal]] by the Royal Society in 1785.
[[File:Anglo-French survey of 1784-1790 Proposed mesh.jpg|center|thumb|800px|The proposed triangulation mesh of the Anglo-French survey 1784–1790.<ref name=roy1787/> For the actual mesh used see [[:File:Anglo-French survey of 1784-1790.jpg]]]] The triangulation itself was delayed until 1787 when Ramsden supplied a [[Ramsden surveying instruments|new theodolite]] of unsurpassed accuracy: it could measure angles to within one arc second and therefore detect the curvature of the Earth by measuring the [[Spherical trigonometry#Area and spherical excess|spherical excess]] of the triangles of the survey. By the end of that year he had completed measurements at all but two of the trigonometric stations. Many of the measurements, particularly the cross channel sightings, were taken at night using intense flares (handled by the artillery). Others required the placing of the instrument on church towers, or even on scaffolded steeples, and in their absence it was sometimes necessary to use a specially constructed portable tower some 30 feet high.
The final report of 1790<ref name=roy1790/> presents figures for the distance between Paris and Greenwich as well as the precise latitude, longitude and height of the British triangulation stations. Throughout the survey Roy took every opportunity to fix the position of as many landmarks as possible and these formed the basis of the [[Topography|topographic]] surveys from which new maps could be prepared. Roy died when only three pages of his final report remained to be proofed.
===Roy's scientific legacy===<!--linked where? -->
Roy's use of scientific advancements and accurate mathematical formulas paved the way for modern geodesic surveying. His tenure and his work are the dividing line between older, approximate mappings and newer, highly accurate ones in Britain. He is cited repeatedly in early nineteenth century mathematics textbooks for his use of [[spherical trigonometry]] in surveying.<ref> {{Harvcolnb|Hutton|1831|pp=26–98}} ''A Course of Mathematics'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=Gw44AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA26 Spherical Trigonometry], for example. </ref> Early twentieth century technical books on modern surveying and geodesy include Roy's work as the historical starting point for the modern profession.<ref>{{Harvcolnb|Popplewell|1915|pp=170–71}} ''The Elements of Surveying and Geodesy'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=wlZDAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA170 Geodetic or Trigonometrical Surveying], for example.</ref> Perhaps his greatest legacy of all was the work of the [[Ordnance Survey]] which commenced in 1791, one year after his death, by extending the basic [[Anglo-French Survey (1784–1790)]] to the rest of Great Britain over the following sixty years.
==Roy as antiquary== [[Image:Rough.Castle.Antonine.Wall.jpg|thumb|Rough Castle, on the Antonine Wall, drawn by William Roy in 1755.]] During the Scottish Survey, Roy took careful note of the locations of ancient [[Rome|Roman]] remains, primarily military camps, wherever he encountered them and these were all marked precisely on the map sheets. This was the beginning of a lifelong interest in ancient Scottish history which he pursued whenever he was travelling the country in his capacity as Surveyor General.<ref>{{harvtxt|Seymour|1980}} p62(true),76(pdf).</ref> Roy's maps and his drawings of the relics of the Roman presence in Scotland were immediately seen as credible and valuable. For sites where the Roman remains were later destroyed by human development, his drawings are the only reliable record of their existence. Roy was the first to systematically map the Antonine Wall and provide accurate and detailed drawings of its remains, an effort undertaken in 1764.<ref> {{Harvcolnb|Hübner|1886|p=111}} ''Archaeologia Aeliana'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=4_4RAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA82 The Roman Annexation of Britain] </ref>
Roy's only historical work, ''Military Antiquities of the Romans in Britain'' was published posthumously in 1793.<ref>{{harvtxt|Roy|1790b}}, ''Military Antiquities of the Romans in Britain.''</ref> This book has a mixed reputation. His drawings and maps are held in the highest regard as still-valuable research sources. However, his efforts in the scholarly discussion of history are widely held to be without value, largely through no fault of his own. This was due to his belief that the spurious text of Charles Bertram ''[[De Situ Britanniae]]'' was a genuine work, a view shared by virtually all of his contemporaries. Roy consequently adjusted his perspective to be consistent with the history as told in the fraud, causing his own conclusions to be without a valid foundation. Much of Roy's research was devoted to the attempt to follow fictitious journeys throughout Scotland that were described in ''De Situ Britanniae''.
That Roy's considerable talents were partially wasted is a tragedy. He was a Scot with a lifelong interest in ancient Scottish history, and his technical ability and scientific knowledge made him uniquely qualified to provide information in an area of history where knowledge and understanding are minimal. That loss for Scottish history has been bemoaned by Scottish historians. In his introduction to ''Celtic Scotland'', [[William Forbes Skene|Skene]] deprecates those historical works based on ''De Situ'', including Roy's, but adds for him alone the comment that " ... perhaps more to be regretted, the valuable work of General Roy ..."<ref>{{Harvcolnb|Skene|1886|p=22}} ''Celtic Scotland'', Introduction, [https://books.google.com/books?id=_kcNAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA22 Notation of Spurious Authorities]</ref>
